content.usage: It's a small scratch; don't make a mountain of a molehill.

extras.mnemonic: A molehill is tiny; a mountain is huge.
extras.origin: Size. Molehill vs Mountain.

meanings.english: To make a lot of money.

content.usage: He made a pile in the stock market.

extras.mnemonic: A pile of gold/money.
extras.origin: Money. Pile.

meanings.english: To correct a mistake; compensate.

content.usage: He bought her flowers to make amends for being late.

extras.mnemonic: Amending (fixing) a wrong.
extras.origin: Repair. Amending.

meanings.english: To live within one's income; survive financially.

content.usage: With rising prices, it's hard to make both ends meet.

extras.mnemonic: Making the income end meet the expense end.
extras.origin: Finance. Ends meet.

meanings.english: To manage with whatever is available.

content.usage: We didn't have a hammer, so we made do with a rock.

extras.mnemonic: Making something 'do' the job even if it's not perfect.
extras.origin: Necessity. Making do.

meanings.english: To enjoy oneself; have fun.

content.usage: The villagers made merry at the festival.

extras.mnemonic: Eat, drink, and be merry.
extras.origin: Feast. Make merry.

meanings.english: To make someone very angry.

content.usage: His arrogant attitude makes my blood boil.

extras.mnemonic: Anger feels like heat inside.
extras.origin: Heat. Blood boil.

meanings.english: To decide.

content.usage: I have made up my mind to resign.

extras.mnemonic: Assembling your thoughts into a decision.
extras.origin: Thought. Making up mind.

meanings.english: To engage in competition; fight.

content.usage: The two champions will measure swords in the finals.

extras.mnemonic: Before a duel, swords were measured to ensure equal length/fairness.
extras.origin: Duel. Measuring swords.

content.phrase: To mind one's P's and Q's

meanings.english: To be careful about one's speech and behavior.
meanings.hindi: शिष्टाचार का ध्यान रखना / सावधानी बरतना।

content.usage: You must mind your P's and Q's when visiting the Queen.

extras.mnemonic: Typesetters had to be careful not to confuse 'p' and 'q'; or bartenders watching 'pints' and 'quarts'.
extras.origin: Print. P and Q.

meanings.english: To miss an opportunity.

content.usage: He missed the boat by not investing in Bitcoin early.

extras.mnemonic: If you are late, the boat leaves without you.
extras.origin: Travel. Missing boat.

meanings.english: To stop something at an early stage.
meanings.hindi: पनपने से पहले ही नष्ट कर देना।

content.usage: We must nip this bad habit in the bud.

extras.mnemonic: Destroying a flower bud prevents it from growing.
extras.origin: Garden. Nip bud.

meanings.english: To not know anything about something.

content.usage: I don't have a clue how to fix this machine.

extras.mnemonic: Without a clue (hint), the puzzle is unsolvable.
extras.origin: Mystery. Clue.

content.phrase: Cut one's coat according to one's cloth

meanings.english: Live within one's means.
meanings.hindi: तेते पाँव पसारिये जेती लांबी सौर / औकात में रहना।

content.usage: We can't afford a luxury car; we must cut our coat according to our cloth.

extras.mnemonic: You can't make a big coat if you only have a small cloth.
extras.origin: Tailor. Coat cloth.

meanings.english: To be independent and self-reliant.
meanings.hindi: आत्मनिर्भर होना / अपनी जिम्मेदारी खुद उठाना।

content.usage: He left home at 18 to paddle his own canoe.

extras.mnemonic: In a canoe, you must row yourself.
extras.origin: Canoe. Paddling alone.

meanings.english: To encounter ultimate defeat.
meanings.hindi: करारी हार होना / अंत आ जाना।

content.usage: The undefeated champion finally met his Waterloo.

extras.mnemonic: Napoleon was finally defeated at the Battle of Waterloo (1815).
extras.origin: Napoleon. Waterloo.

meanings.english: To take revenge.
meanings.hindi: पुराना हिसाब चुकता करना / बदला लेना।

content.usage: He used his power to pay off old scores with his enemies.

extras.mnemonic: Settling the score (debt) of insults.
extras.origin: Debt. Scores.

meanings.english: Pay an extremely high price.
meanings.hindi: मुंहमांगी कीमत देना / बहुत ज्यादा पैसा खर्चना।

content.usage: We paid through the nose for those concert tickets.

extras.mnemonic: Possible link to 'nose tax' in Ireland or bleeding money.
extras.origin: Tax. Nose slit.

meanings.english: To criticize someone; find faults.

content.usage: It's easy to pick holes in someone else's work.

extras.mnemonic: Finding tiny holes in fabric to reject it.
extras.origin: Cloth. Picking holes.

meanings.english: To restart from the previous closing point.
meanings.hindi: सिलसिला वहीं से जोड़ना जहाँ टूटा था।

content.usage: After the break, we picked up the threads of our conversation.

extras.mnemonic: Ideally weaving or sewing where you left off.
extras.origin: Weaving. Threads.

meanings.english: To categorize unfairly; put aside.
meanings.hindi: खांचे में बांटना / ठंडे बस्ते में डालना।

content.usage: Don't pigeonhole me as just a comedian; I can act drama too.

extras.mnemonic: Pigeonholes are small compartments in a desk for sorting mail.
extras.origin: Desk. Pigeonholes.

meanings.english: Behave irresponsibly or immorally.

content.usage: You can't play fast and loose with people's feelings.

extras.mnemonic: From a cheating fairground game 'Fast and Loose'.
extras.origin: Fair game. Fast and Loose.

meanings.english: To be in a subordinate role.
meanings.hindi: दोयम दर्जे का होना / सहायक भूमिका निभाना।

content.usage: He tired of playing second fiddle to his partner.

extras.mnemonic: In an orchestra, the first fiddle leads; the second supports.
extras.origin: Orchestra. Second fiddle.

meanings.english: To propose marriage.

content.usage: He plans to pop the question on Valentine's Day.

extras.mnemonic: Popping out the most important question.
extras.origin: Marriage. Pop question.

meanings.english: Encourage the growth or action of something (usually financially).

content.usage: The government cut taxes to prime the pump of the economy.

extras.mnemonic: You pour water into an old pump to get it started.
extras.origin: Pump. Priming.

meanings.english: To behave in a way intended to make people admire you; cheap popularity.
meanings.hindi: जनता को खुश करना / दिखावा करना।

content.usage: His speeches are just playing to the gallery.

extras.mnemonic: Acting for the cheap seats (gallery) rather than the critics.
extras.origin: Theater. Gallery.

content.phrase: To pour oil on troubled waters

meanings.english: To calm a dispute.

content.usage: The mother poured oil on troubled waters when the siblings fought.

extras.mnemonic: Oil floats on water and smooths the waves.
extras.origin: Sea. Oil on water.

meanings.english: To cheat or deceive someone.

content.usage: Don't let him pull a fast one on you with that contract.

extras.mnemonic: Moving too fast to be seen (sleight of hand).
extras.origin: Trick. Fast one.

meanings.english: To make fun of someone; tease.

content.usage: I was just pulling your leg; I didn't really win the lottery.

extras.mnemonic: Tripping someone up metaphorically.
extras.origin: Trip. Pulling leg.

content.phrase: To put a spoke in one's wheel

meanings.english: To hinder; thwart plans.

content.usage: His refusal put a spoke in our wheel.

extras.mnemonic: Jamming a stick (spoke) into a spinning wheel stops it.
extras.origin: Wheel. Spoke.

meanings.english: To make ashamed or disconcerted.

content.usage: Her stare put him out of countenance.

extras.mnemonic: Countenance = face/composure; losing it means looking ashamed.
extras.origin: Face. Countenance.

meanings.english: Stop; abolish.

content.usage: The new law will put an end to this practice.

extras.mnemonic: Placing an 'End' sign on something.
extras.origin: Stop. Put end.

content.phrase: To put one's foot in one's mouth

meanings.english: To accidentally embarrass or upset someone; say something stupid.
meanings.hindi: मुंह से गलत बात निकल जाना / शर्मिंदा होना।

content.usage: I really put my foot in my mouth by asking about her ex-husband.

extras.mnemonic: Ideally, only food goes in the mouth; putting a foot in is clumsy and blocks speech.
extras.origin: Blunder. Foot in mouth.

content.phrase: To put someone to the sword

meanings.english: To slay or execute someone.

content.usage: The invaders put the entire village to the sword.

extras.mnemonic: Applying the sword to the person.
extras.origin: War. Sword.

content.phrase: To put one's hand to the plough

meanings.english: Get busy working; start a difficult task.

content.usage: Once you put your hand to the plough, you shouldn't look back.

extras.mnemonic: Ploughing a field requires holding the plough firmly and moving forward.
extras.origin: Farm. Plough.

meanings.english: To postpone something.

content.usage: We have to put the party on hold until he recovers.

extras.mnemonic: Holding a phone call; waiting.
extras.origin: Phone. Hold.

meanings.english: Tolerate; endure.

content.usage: I can't put up with his rude behavior anymore.

extras.mnemonic: Phrasal verb.
extras.origin: Endurance. Put up.

meanings.english: To stop helping someone especially when support is needed.

content.usage: Don't quit on me now; we're almost finished.

extras.mnemonic: Quitting the job of being a friend/helper.
extras.origin: Abandon. Quit.

meanings.english: To cause disruption or confusion.

content.usage: His comments raised a dust in the media.

extras.mnemonic: Running/fighting kicks up dust, blinding others.
extras.origin: Dust. Raising dust.

meanings.english: To obtain necessary funds.

content.usage: He pawned his watch to raise the wind for rent.

extras.mnemonic: Sailors whistling to 'raise the wind' for sailing; needing resources to move.
extras.origin: Sailing. Raising wind.

content.phrase: To roll out the red carpet

meanings.english: To give a grand welcome.

content.usage: They rolled out the red carpet for the visiting President.

extras.mnemonic: Red carpets are laid for royalty/VIPs.
extras.origin: VIP. Red carpet.

content.phrase: To rub salt in someone's wound

meanings.english: To make a bad situation worse; aggravate pain.

content.usage: Laughing at his failure was just rubbing salt in his wound.

extras.mnemonic: Salt stings painfully on raw flesh.
extras.origin: Pain. Salt in wound.

meanings.english: To meet someone by chance.

content.usage: I ran across an old diary while cleaning.

extras.mnemonic: Crossing paths while running/walking.
extras.origin: Meeting. Run across.

meanings.english: To behave uncontrollably and disruptively; go mad.

content.usage: The crowd ran amok after the concert was cancelled.

extras.mnemonic: From Malay 'amuk' meaning attacking furiously.
extras.origin: Malay. Amok.

content.phrase: To run around like a headless chicken

meanings.english: To do many things in a disorganized manner.
meanings.hindi: बदहवास होकर दौड़ना / बिना दिशा के भागना।

content.usage: Calm down; stop running around like a headless chicken.

extras.mnemonic: A chicken continues to run aimlessly for seconds after being beheaded.
extras.origin: Farm. Headless chicken.

meanings.english: To disparage someone; criticize unfairly.

content.usage: He is always running his brother down out of jealousy.

extras.mnemonic: Running over someone (figuratively crushing them).
extras.origin: Driving. Run down.

meanings.english: To increase in size, number, or importance.

content.usage: The company plans to scale up production next year.

extras.mnemonic: Climbing up the scale (ladder/graph).
extras.origin: Climbing. Scale up.

meanings.english: To put something extra aside; save; annul.
meanings.hindi: बचत करना / रद्द करना / अलग रखना।

content.usage: The court set aside the verdict. / He sets aside money for holidays.

extras.mnemonic: Putting it to the side for later or discarding.
extras.origin: Storage. Set aside.

content.phrase: To set the Thames on fire

meanings.english: Do a heroic or wonderful deed (often used negatively: he won't set the Thames on fire).
meanings.hindi: अनोखा काम करना / दुनिया हिला देना।

content.usage: He's a nice boy, but he'll never set the Thames on fire.

extras.mnemonic: It's impossible to burn a river; doing so would be a miracle.
extras.origin: River. Thames fire.

meanings.english: To be afraid.

content.usage: The bully made the little boy shake in his shoes.

extras.mnemonic: Trembling so hard your shoes vibrate.
extras.origin: Fear. Shaking shoes.

meanings.english: False tears; pretending to be sad.

content.usage: She shed crocodile tears at the funeral of her rich uncle.

extras.mnemonic: Crocodiles were believed to weep while eating their prey to lure victims.
extras.origin: Myth. Crocodile tears.

content.phrase: To show a clean pair of heels

meanings.english: Run away; escape.
meanings.hindi: नौ दो ग्यारह होना / भाग जाना।

content.usage: The thief showed a clean pair of heels as soon as the police arrived.

extras.mnemonic: When running away fast, you lift your heels high so they are visible.
extras.origin: Running. Clean heels.

meanings.english: To take action that causes future trouble or conflict.

content.usage: The harsh treaty sowed dragon's teeth for the next war.

extras.mnemonic: In myth, Cadmus sowed dragon teeth which turned into armed soldiers who fought each other.
extras.origin: Myth. Dragon teeth.

content.phrase: To sit at the feet of someone

meanings.english: To be a disciple or student of someone.

content.usage: He sat at the feet of the great musician to learn the art.

extras.mnemonic: Students traditionally sat on the floor while the master sat on a chair.
extras.origin: School. Sit at feet.

meanings.english: To sleep soundly.
meanings.hindi: घोड़े बेचकर सोना / गहरी नींद सोना।

content.usage: After the hike, I slept like a dog.

extras.mnemonic: Dogs sleep deeply and comfortably.
extras.origin: Sleep. Dog sleep.

meanings.english: To avoid deliberately; keep away from.

content.usage: She shuns publicity and lives a quiet life.

extras.mnemonic: Sounds like 'shun' (to push away).
extras.origin: Old English. Shun.

meanings.english: Suspect a trick or deceit.
meanings.hindi: दाल में काला लगना / शक होना।

content.usage: When he offered me the car for $50, I smelt a rat.

extras.mnemonic: A cat smells a rat hidden nearby; sensing something hidden and bad.
extras.origin: Cats. Smell rat.

meanings.english: Raise an alarm; warn of danger.
meanings.hindi: खतरे की घंटी बजाना / चेतावनी देना।

content.usage: The scientists sounded a red alert about the melting glaciers.

extras.mnemonic: Red is the color of danger.
extras.origin: Alarm. Red alert.

meanings.english: To express one's thoughts frankly.
meanings.hindi: मन की बात कहना / स्पष्ट बोलना।

content.usage: He is never afraid to speak his mind.

extras.mnemonic: Letting out what is in the mind.
extras.origin: Speech. Speak mind.

content.phrase: To stand on one's own feet

meanings.english: To be strong and independent.
meanings.hindi: अपने पैरों पर खड़ा होना / आत्मनिर्भर होना।

content.usage: It's time you got a job and stood on your own feet.

extras.mnemonic: Supporting your own weight without crutches or help.
extras.origin: Posture. Stand feet.

meanings.english: Postpone; ward off.

content.usage: He ate a snack to stave off hunger.

extras.mnemonic: Using a staff (stave) to push something away.
extras.origin: Defense. Stave off.

meanings.english: Gain an advantage unexpectedly or secretly.
meanings.hindi: चुपके से आगे निकल जाना / बाजी मार लेना।

content.usage: Our company stole a march on competitors by launching the product early.

extras.mnemonic: Moving troops at night (stealing a march) to get ahead of the enemy.
extras.origin: Army. Steal march.

meanings.english: Take credit or attention away from someone else.
meanings.hindi: श्रेय ले लेना / किसी का प्रभाव कम करना।

content.usage: See ID 744.

extras.mnemonic: See ID 744.
extras.origin: Theater. Steal thunder.

meanings.english: Avoid.

content.usage: I try to steer clear of trouble.

extras.mnemonic: Steering a ship away from rocks/danger.
extras.origin: Ship. Steer clear.

meanings.english: Relax; calm down.

content.usage: Stop shouting and take a chill pill.

extras.mnemonic: A medicine (pill) that makes you chill (relax).
extras.origin: Drug. Chill pill.

meanings.english: To take a risk.

content.usage: I stuck my neck out for you, and you betrayed me.

extras.mnemonic: A chicken sticking its neck out on the chopping block risks getting it cut.
extras.origin: Execution. Neck out.

meanings.english: Give up control; take a subordinate position.

content.usage: After retiring, he decided to take a back seat in the company.

extras.mnemonic: Sitting in the back of the car implies you aren't driving (controlling).
extras.origin: Car. Back seat.

meanings.english: To assess a situation; survey.

content.usage: After the disaster, we need to take stock of our supplies.

extras.mnemonic: Counting the stock (inventory) in a shop to know what you have.
extras.origin: Shop. Take stock.

meanings.english: To accept without question; undervalue.
meanings.hindi: हल्के में लेना / अहमियत न समझना।

content.usage: Don't take your health for granted.

extras.mnemonic: Assuming something is granted (given) forever.
extras.origin: Gift. Granted.

meanings.english: Absent oneself without permission.

content.usage: The soldier was punished for taking French leave.

extras.mnemonic: 18th-century custom of leaving a party without saying goodbye (considered rude by English).
extras.origin: Manners. French leave.

meanings.english: To consider.

content.usage: You must take his age into account before judging him.

extras.mnemonic: Putting it into the calculation (account).
extras.origin: Math. Account.

content.phrase: To take one's hat off to

meanings.english: To admire someone.

content.usage: I take my hat off to her courage.

extras.mnemonic: Removing hat is a gesture of respect.
extras.origin: Hat. Take off.

meanings.english: To make efforts; try hard.

content.usage: She took great pains to decorate the house.

extras.mnemonic: Enduring pain (trouble) to get it right.
extras.origin: Effort. Pains.

content.phrase: To take someone for a ride

meanings.english: To deceive someone.

content.usage: I paid for the goods but never received them; I was taken for a ride.

extras.mnemonic: Gangsters taking a victim for a 'ride' to kill or rob them.
extras.origin: Gangster. Ride.

meanings.english: To be greatly affected; take seriously.

content.usage: Don't take his criticism to heart; he's just grumpy.

extras.mnemonic: Allowing words to enter your heart and hurt/affect you.
extras.origin: Emotion. Heart.

meanings.english: Reprimand; criticize.

content.usage: The teacher took him to task for not doing homework.

extras.mnemonic: Forcing someone to focus on the 'task' or fault.
extras.origin: Work. Task.

meanings.english: To convince someone.

content.usage: He didn't want to come, but I managed to talk him over.

extras.mnemonic: Talking until they cross over to your side.
extras.origin: Speech. Talk over.

meanings.english: In every detail; exactly.

content.usage: She followed the instructions to the letter.

extras.mnemonic: Following every single letter written.
extras.origin: Writing. Letter.

meanings.english: To perfection.
meanings.hindi: पूरी तरह से / शानदार ढंग से।

content.usage: She was dressed to the nines for the gala.

extras.mnemonic: 9 is the highest single digit; implies highest degree.
extras.origin: Numbers. Nines.

meanings.english: To become very angry.

content.usage: His face went purple with rage when he saw the bill.

extras.mnemonic: Extreme anger stops breath or rushes blood, turning the face purple.
extras.origin: Face. Purple.

meanings.english: Naturally at ease; accustomed from birth.

content.usage: He handles luxury cars as if to the manner born.

extras.mnemonic: Born into the custom (manner).
extras.origin: Shakespeare. Manner born.

meanings.english: To behave cautiously.

content.usage: You need to tread carefully when discussing politics with him.

extras.mnemonic: Walking carefully to avoid stepping on dangerous things.
extras.origin: Walking. Tread.

meanings.english: To challenge somebody.

content.usage: See ID 822.

extras.mnemonic: See ID 822.
extras.origin: Glove. Gauntlet.

meanings.english: Express extreme anger.

content.usage: The child threw a fit when denied candy.

extras.mnemonic: Acting like one is having a medical fit due to anger.
extras.origin: Medical. Fit.

meanings.english: Follow the rules; conform.
meanings.hindi: नियमों का पालन करना / लकीर पर चलना।

content.usage: In the army, you have to toe the line.

extras.mnemonic: Standing with toes exactly on the line (military/runners).
extras.origin: Line. Toe line.

content.phrase: To turn over a new leaf

meanings.english: To change one's behavior for better.

content.usage: After prison, he turned over a new leaf and started working.

extras.mnemonic: Turning a page (leaf) of a book to a clean, fresh page.
extras.origin: Book. New leaf.

meanings.english: Feel elated; extremely happy.

content.usage: She was walking on air after getting the promotion.

extras.mnemonic: Feeling so light with happiness that you float.
extras.origin: Flight. Walk on air.

meanings.english: To achieve honours or glory.

content.usage: He won laurels for his bravery.

extras.mnemonic: See 'Laurels' (ID 460).
extras.origin: Wreath. Laurels.

meanings.english: To work very diligently and hard.
meanings.hindi: कोल्हू के बैल की तरह काम करना / जी-तोड़ मेहनत।

content.usage: He worked like a dog to finish the project.

extras.mnemonic: Dogs (farm dogs) work hard all day.
extras.origin: Farm. Work dog.

content.phrase: To wrangle over an ass's shadow

meanings.english: To quarrel over trifles.

content.usage: Stop wrangling over an ass's shadow and solve the main issue.

extras.mnemonic: Fable where men fought over sitting in the shadow of a rented donkey.
extras.origin: Fable. Ass shadow.

meanings.english: Short strike held as a warning.

content.usage: The workers called a one-day token strike.

extras.mnemonic: A token is a symbol; a symbolic strike.
extras.origin: Symbol. Token.

meanings.english: In an ironic or insincere way; joking.

content.usage: His comments were made tongue in cheek.

extras.mnemonic: Pushing your tongue into your cheek to suppress a laugh.
extras.origin: Gesture. Tongue cheek.

meanings.english: So close to danger that it causes worry.
meanings.hindi: बाल-बाल बचना / खतरे के बहुत करीब।

content.usage: The lightning struck a tree nearby—too close for comfort.

extras.mnemonic: If it was any closer, it would be uncomfortable/painful.
extras.origin: Danger. Close.

meanings.english: Impossible to predict who will win.

content.usage: The race is too close to call.

extras.mnemonic: See ID 880.
extras.origin: Race. Close call.

content.phrase: Too fond of one's own voice

meanings.english: Talks too much; doesn't listen.

content.usage: He is too fond of his own voice to let anyone else speak.

extras.mnemonic: Loving the sound of your own voice.
extras.origin: Speech. Voice.

content.phrase: Too many chiefs, not enough Indians

meanings.english: Too many managers and not enough workers; inefficient.

content.usage: The project failed because there were too many chiefs and not enough Indians.

extras.mnemonic: Refers to Native American tribes; everyone wants to be leader.
extras.origin: Tribe. Chiefs Indians.

content.phrase: Too many irons in the fire

meanings.english: Engaged in too many enterprises at once.
meanings.hindi: एक साथ कई काम हाथ में लेना।

content.usage: He is stressed because he has too many irons in the fire.

extras.mnemonic: Blacksmith putting too many metal pieces in the forge at once; can't hammer them all.
extras.origin: Forge. Irons fire.

content.phrase: Took a leap in the dark

meanings.english: Took a risk without knowing the outcome.
meanings.hindi: अंधेरे में छलांग लगाना / जोखिम उठाना।

content.usage: Starting a business was a leap in the dark.

extras.mnemonic: Jumping where you can't see the landing.
extras.origin: Jump. Leap dark.

meanings.english: Objected; disagreed strongly.

content.usage: He took exception to the unfair rules.

extras.mnemonic: See 'Take exception to' (ID 766).
extras.origin: Law. Exception.

meanings.english: Ran away.

content.usage: See ID 774.

extras.mnemonic: See ID 774.
extras.origin: Run. Heels.

meanings.english: With all their might; fiercely.

content.usage: See ID 901.

extras.mnemonic: See ID 901.
extras.origin: Fight. Tooth nail.

meanings.english: Include everything; ensure all details are covered.

content.usage: Before launching, ensure you touch all bases.

extras.mnemonic: In baseball, you must touch every base to score.
extras.origin: Baseball. Bases.

meanings.english: Extremely uncertain or risky.

content.usage: The surgery was touch and go, but he survived.

extras.mnemonic: A ship touching the bottom but keeping going; a close call.
extras.origin: Ship. Touch go.

meanings.english: Something that gives an advantage.

content.usage: He played his trump card at the end of the negotiation.

extras.mnemonic: A card suit that beats all others.
extras.origin: Cards. Trump.

meanings.english: To pass the critical stage; start improving.
meanings.hindi: संकट से बाहर आना / सुधार की ओर।

content.usage: The economy has finally turned the corner and is growing.

extras.mnemonic: Turning the corner allows you to see a new, clear path.
extras.origin: Turn. Corner.

meanings.english: Special skills or techniques known to professionals.

content.usage: He taught me the tricks of the trade in carpentry.

extras.mnemonic: Clever methods used in a specific trade.
extras.origin: Magic. Tricks.

meanings.english: Change one's opinion or side.

content.usage: He is a turncoat; he switched parties for money.

extras.mnemonic: Turning a coat inside out to hide the badge/colour of allegiance.
extras.origin: Coat. Turncoat.

meanings.english: Disregard; refuse to obey.

content.usage: He turned a deaf ear to my warnings.

extras.mnemonic: Presenting the ear that cannot hear.
extras.origin: Hearing. Deaf ear.

meanings.english: Make a legitimate living.

content.usage: He works hard to turn an honest penny.

extras.mnemonic: Making money (pennies) honestly.
extras.origin: Money. Penny.

meanings.english: To ignore something deliberately.

content.usage: The teacher turned a blind eye to the student's mistake.

extras.mnemonic: Admiral Nelson put the telescope to his blind eye to ignore the signal to retreat.
extras.origin: Nelson. Blind eye.

meanings.english: Real character or personality.

content.usage: In times of crisis, people show their true colours.

extras.mnemonic: Ships flying their real country's flag (colours) instead of a fake one.
extras.origin: Flag. Colours.

meanings.english: Reject.

content.usage: She turned down the job offer.

extras.mnemonic: Turning a page down (closing); refusing.
extras.origin: Page. Turn down.

meanings.english: To try new things; be able to do.
meanings.hindi: हाथ आजमाना / कोई काम कर लेना।

content.usage: She can turn her hand to carpentry or sewing.

extras.mnemonic: Applying your hand to a task.
extras.origin: Work. Hand.

content.phrase: Two heads are better than one

meanings.english: It is helpful to take advice; collaboration is better.

content.usage: Let's work together; two heads are better than one.

extras.mnemonic: More brains = better solutions.
extras.origin: Advice. Heads.

meanings.english: Overturn; turn upside down.

content.usage: The car turned turtle in the accident.

extras.mnemonic: A turtle on its back is helpless and upside down.
extras.origin: Sea. Turtle.

meanings.english: Appear.

content.usage: He finally turned up at the party.

extras.mnemonic: Turning up around a corner.
extras.origin: Corner. Turn up.

meanings.english: Caused to become conceited; infatuated.

content.usage: Success has turned his head.

extras.mnemonic: Looking away from others in pride; or dizziness from ego.
extras.origin: Vanity. Head turn.

meanings.english: Treat with contempt; despise.

content.usage: She turned up her nose at the cheap gift.

extras.mnemonic: Lifting the nose as if smelling something bad.
extras.origin: Smell. Nose up.

meanings.english: Feeling bored; doing nothing.

content.usage: I was just twiddling my thumbs waiting for you.

extras.mnemonic: Circling thumbs around each other is a sign of idleness.
extras.origin: Boredom. Thumbs.

meanings.english: Force or persuade someone to do something.

content.usage: I didn't want to go, but he twisted my arm.

extras.mnemonic: Applying physical pain to force compliance.
extras.origin: Pain. Twist arm.

meanings.english: Under suspicion; in disgrace.
meanings.hindi: शक के घेरे में / बदनामी में।

content.usage: He left the company under a cloud of suspicion.

extras.mnemonic: A dark cloud hanging over a person implies gloom/trouble.
extras.origin: Weather. Cloud.

meanings.english: Under pressure; forced.

content.usage: He signed the confession under duress.

extras.mnemonic: Duress = force/threat.
extras.origin: Force. Duress.

meanings.english: Right in front of him.

content.usage: The theft happened right under his nose.

extras.mnemonic: So close you can smell it.
extras.origin: Smell. Nose.

meanings.english: On earth; everywhere.

content.usage: We talked about everything under the sun.

extras.mnemonic: Everything the sun shines on.
extras.origin: Earth. Sun.

meanings.english: To feel ill or sick.

content.usage: I'm feeling a bit under the weather today.

extras.mnemonic: Sailors feeling seasick went below deck (under the weather rail).
extras.origin: Sailor. Weather.

meanings.english: To be under pressure.

content.usage: We are under the gun to finish the report by 5 PM.

extras.mnemonic: Facing a gun implies extreme pressure.
extras.origin: Gun. Pressure.

content.phrase: United we stand, divided we fall

meanings.english: Unity gives strength.

content.usage: The team motto is: United we stand, divided we fall.

extras.mnemonic: Standing together supports the structure; separating causes collapse.
extras.origin: Aesop. United.

meanings.english: Following a course that leads nowhere.
meanings.hindi: गलत रास्ते पर / बंद गली में।

content.usage: This research is taking us up a blind alley.

extras.mnemonic: Walking into an alley with no exit.
extras.origin: City. Alley.

meanings.english: In an inextricable situation; in trouble.
meanings.hindi: मुसीबत में / दीवार से सटा हुआ।

content.usage: With debts piling up, he is up against the wall.

extras.mnemonic: Being backed against a wall with no escape route.
extras.origin: Execution. Wall.

meanings.english: To be angry; protesting vigorously.
meanings.hindi: विरोध में खड़ा होना / गुस्से में।

content.usage: The residents are up in arms about the new highway.

extras.mnemonic: Picking up weapons (arms) to fight.
extras.origin: Rebellion. Arms.

meanings.english: As good as expected; up to standard.
meanings.hindi: उम्मीद के मुताबिक / स्तर के अनुरूप।

content.usage: His work is not up to the mark.

extras.mnemonic: Reaching the required mark/level.
extras.origin: Measure. Mark.

meanings.english: To cause trouble, especially by spoiling someone's plans.

content.usage: We were ready to leave, but the rain upset our applecart.

extras.mnemonic: If a farmer's cart of apples is knocked over, his business plan for the day is ruined.
extras.origin: Market. Applecart.

meanings.english: Completely disappear.
meanings.hindi: हवा हो जाना / गायब हो जाना।

content.usage: The thief seemed to vanish into thin air.

extras.mnemonic: Disappearing so completely as if turning into air.
extras.origin: Magic. Thin air.

meanings.english: In relation to; face to face.

content.usage: We need to discuss our strategy vis-a-vis the new competitor.

extras.mnemonic: French for 'face to face'.
extras.origin: French. Vis-a-vis.

meanings.english: Show disapproval by leaving a place or organization.

content.usage: Customers voted with their feet and stopped buying the expensive product.

extras.mnemonic: Using your feet to walk away is a form of voting 'no'.
extras.origin: Walk. Vote feet.

meanings.english: To do what one says; keep promises.

content.usage: A good leader must walk the talk.

extras.mnemonic: Walking (acting) according to your talking.
extras.origin: Business. Walk talk.

meanings.english: Be very cautious; deal with a difficult situation.
meanings.hindi: फूंक-फूंक कर कदम रखना / नाजुक स्थिति संभालना।

content.usage: The minister is walking a tightrope between two warring factions.

extras.mnemonic: Balancing on a thin rope requires extreme caution.
extras.origin: Circus. Tightrope.

meanings.english: Doing something risky.
meanings.hindi: खतरे में होना / मुसीबत मोल लेना।

content.usage: You are walking on thin ice by arguing with the boss.

extras.mnemonic: Ice that is thin breaks easily, causing you to fall into freezing water.
extras.origin: Winter. Thin ice.

meanings.english: Refuse to be responsible for something.
meanings.hindi: पल्ला झाड़ लेना / जिम्मेदारी से मुकर जाना।

content.usage: I wash my hands of this mess; you fix it.

extras.mnemonic: Pontius Pilate washed his hands to show he was innocent of Jesus' death.
extras.origin: Pilate. Wash hands.

meanings.english: Very boring.

content.usage: Cricket is like watching grass grow for some people.

extras.mnemonic: Grass grows so slowly it is invisible and boring to watch.
extras.origin: Boring. Grass grow.

meanings.english: Past events that are no longer important or worth arguing about.
meanings.hindi: रात गई बात गई / पुरानी बात।

content.usage: We argued yesterday, but it's water under the bridge now.

extras.mnemonic: Water that has flowed past the bridge cannot return.
extras.origin: River. Water bridge.

meanings.english: Good times and bad times; joys and sorrows.

content.usage: They shared weal and woe throughout their marriage.

extras.mnemonic: Weal (wealth/well-being) and Woe (misery).
extras.origin: Old. Weal woe.

meanings.english: Damage caused by ordinary use.

content.usage: The sofa shows signs of wear and tear.

extras.mnemonic: Wearing down and tearing apart.
extras.origin: Use. Wear tear.

meanings.english: Expresses feelings openly.
meanings.hindi: दिल खोलकर रख देना / भावनाएं छिपा न पाना।

content.usage: He wears his heart on his sleeve, so everyone knows he likes her.

extras.mnemonic: Knights tied a lady's favour (scarf) to their sleeve to show loyalty/love.
extras.origin: Sleeve. Heart.

meanings.english: Suffer unrequited love; grieve for a lost lover.
meanings.hindi: वियोग में होना / प्यार में धोखा खाना।

content.usage: She is wearing the green willow for her boyfriend who joined the army.

extras.mnemonic: Willow trees (weeping willows) symbolize grief and lost love.
extras.origin: Grief. Willow.

meanings.english: Survive a period of difficulty.
meanings.hindi: मुसीबत का सामना करना और बच निकलना।

content.usage: The company managed to weather the storm of the recession.

extras.mnemonic: A ship surviving through a storm without sinking.
extras.origin: Ship. Storm.

meanings.english: Dawn; very early morning (after midnight).

content.usage: He woke up in the wee hours of the day to catch the flight.

extras.mnemonic: Wee means small; the small numbers on the clock (1, 2, 3 AM).
extras.origin: Small. Wee.

meanings.english: Helped considerably.

content.usage: His advice went a long way in solving my problem.

extras.mnemonic: Travelling a long distance implies covering a lot of ground/help.
extras.origin: Travel. Long way.

meanings.english: Dissipated; lost; scattered.

content.usage: All his promises went to the winds after he was elected.

extras.mnemonic: Blown away by the wind.
extras.origin: Wind. Gone.

meanings.english: Have a drink (often alcohol).

content.usage: We stopped at the pub to wet our whistles.

extras.mnemonic: If your throat (whistle) is dry, you can't make sound; wetting it helps.
extras.origin: Throat. Whistle.

meanings.english: Complications; intricate details; secret motives.

content.usage: The politics of this office are complex, wheels within wheels.

extras.mnemonic: Gears inside gears imply complex machinery.
extras.origin: Gears. Wheels.

meanings.english: Something that will never happen.

content.usage: I'll apologize when pigs fly.

extras.mnemonic: Pigs are heavy and have no wings; impossible event.
extras.origin: Impossible. Pigs fly.

meanings.english: The situation turns unpleasant or serious; trouble begins.

content.usage: When the balloon goes up, we must be ready to fight.

extras.mnemonic: Observation balloons rising signaled the start of an artillery bombardment in WWI.
extras.origin: War. Balloon.

meanings.english: To want something more; stimulate interest.

content.usage: The trailer was just enough to whet my appetite for the movie.

extras.mnemonic: Whet means to sharpen (like a knife); sharpening the appetite.
extras.origin: Sharpen. Whet.

meanings.english: Pretend to be unafraid.

content.usage: He says he's confident, but he's just whistling in the dark.

extras.mnemonic: Whistling while walking in the dark to distract oneself from fear.
extras.origin: Fear. Whistle.

meanings.english: Make use of all possibilities or techniques.

content.usage: He used his whole bag of tricks to win the election.

extras.mnemonic: A magician's bag contains all their tricks.
extras.origin: Magic. Bag tricks.

meanings.english: The entirety of something; everything.

content.usage: He didn't just paint the car, he gave it new tires and seats—the whole nine yards.

extras.mnemonic: Ammo belts for machine guns were 9 yards long; firing it all meant giving everything.
extras.origin: Ammo. 9 yards.

meanings.english: Irrelevant; inaccurate.

content.usage: Your guess was wide off the mark.

extras.mnemonic: An arrow landing far from the target (mark).
extras.origin: Arrow. Mark.

meanings.english: Uncouth in appearance or behavior; untamed.

content.usage: The party got a bit wild and woolly after midnight.

extras.mnemonic: Refers to the untamed American West (Wild West) and sheepskin coats.
extras.origin: West. Woolly.

meanings.english: Treat somebody to an expensive meal.

content.usage: The company wined and dined the clients to sign the deal.

extras.mnemonic: Serving wine and dinner.
extras.origin: Rhyme. Wine dine.

meanings.english: Something impossible to get or achieve; unreal imagining.

content.usage: Chasing perfect happiness is often a will-o'-the-wisp.

extras.mnemonic: Atmospheric ghost light seen in swamps that misleads travelers.
extras.origin: Swamp. Wisp.

meanings.english: To cheat or deceive someone.

content.usage: The salesman wiped his nose by selling him a broken car.

extras.mnemonic: Related to 'wiping someone's eye' (shooting their game bird); treating them like a child/fool.
extras.origin: Trick. Wipe nose.

meanings.english: Cordially; warmly.

content.usage: They welcomed the refugees with open arms.

extras.mnemonic: Opening arms to hug someone.
extras.origin: Hug. Arms.

meanings.english: With intense degree; with great force.
meanings.hindi: पूरी ताकत से / बदला लेने की भावना से।

content.usage: The rain came down with a vengeance.

extras.mnemonic: Doing something as hard as if you were taking revenge.
extras.origin: Revenge. Vengeance.

meanings.english: In anxiety or suspense.

content.usage: We waited with bated breath for the winner announcement.

extras.mnemonic: Abated (stopped/held) breath due to suspense.
extras.origin: Breath. Bated.

meanings.english: Unanimously.

content.usage: The committee decided with one voice to elect him.

extras.mnemonic: Everyone speaking the same thing at once.
extras.origin: Choir. Voice.

meanings.english: Without a reasonable explanation; nonsensical.

content.usage: He fired the staff without rhyme or reason.

extras.mnemonic: Neither poetry (rhyme) nor logic (reason).
extras.origin: Poetry. Rhyme reason.

content.phrase: Want to curl up and die

meanings.english: To feel very ashamed or embarrassed.

content.usage: I was so embarrassed I just wanted to curl up and die.

extras.mnemonic: Trying to make oneself small (curl up) and disappear (die) from shame.
extras.origin: Shame. Curl die.

meanings.english: Through the verbal sharing of information.

content.usage: The news spread by word of mouth.

extras.mnemonic: Passing from one mouth to another ear.
extras.origin: Before writing, news traveled only by speech. Passing information from one mouth to another ear was the only way to spread news.

meanings.english: Work very fast to complete something within a deadline.
meanings.hindi: समय के साथ दौड़ लगाना / जल्दी काम करना।

content.usage: We are working against the clock to finish the report.

extras.mnemonic: Racing against time.
extras.origin: Racing against time. Imagine a clock is your opponent in a race; you must finish the work before the hands hit the deadline.

meanings.english: To work very well or effectively.

content.usage: The new medicine worked like a charm.

extras.mnemonic: A magic charm always produces the desired effect.
extras.origin: Magic. A charm or spell is supposed to work perfectly and instantly. If a plan works like a charm, it has magical efficiency.

meanings.english: A plan succeeded perfectly.

content.usage: Our plan worked like a dream.

extras.mnemonic: Dreams are often perfect/ideal.
extras.origin: Sleep. Dreams are often perfect worlds where everything goes right. A plan working like a dream goes perfectly smoothly.

meanings.english: Very valuable.

content.usage: A good mechanic is worth his weight in gold.

extras.mnemonic: If something weighed the same as gold, it would be expensive.
extras.origin: Roman law. Gold is dense and heavy. If a person or thing were made of solid gold, they would be incredibly valuable.

meanings.english: To comprehend something challenging or confusing.

content.usage: I can't wrap my head around the new physics theory.

extras.mnemonic: Mentally surrounding the idea to grasp it.
extras.origin: 20th-century slang. Imagine your brain physically wrapping itself around a difficult concept to grasp and contain it.

meanings.english: Excellent service; useful help in need.

content.usage: The volunteers did yeoman service during the flood.

extras.mnemonic: Yeomen were hardworking farmers/soldiers known for reliability.
extras.origin: Shakespeare (Hamlet). Yeomen were small landowners who served as reliable soldiers. 'Yeoman service' means dependable, hard work.

content.phrase: Your guess is as good as mine

meanings.english: To have no idea of the answer.

content.usage: Where did he go? Your guess is as good as mine.

extras.mnemonic: We both know nothing, so any guess is equal.
extras.origin: Equality. We both know nothing about the answer, so my random guess is just as likely to be right as yours.

meanings.english: The time has come when someone is doomed to suffer a disaster or die.
meanings.hindi: बुरा वक्त आ जाना / मौत का समय।

content.usage: When the enemy surrounded him, he knew his number was up.

extras.mnemonic: In lottery/military draft, when your number is called, you are chosen (for duty/death).
extras.origin: Military/Lottery. In a draft or lottery, everyone has a number. When your number is called ('up'), it's your turn for duty—or death.

meanings.english: Huge attraction; something or someone that attracts a large audience.

content.usage: The new superhero movie proved to be a big draw for the cinema this weekend.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Big' means Huge and 'Draw' means To Pull. Visual: Imagine a massive magnet in the city center. It has the power to 'draw' (pull) metal objects towards it. Connect the dots: A 'Big Draw' is a person or event acting like that magnet, pulling a massive audience to the venue.
extras.origin: Originated in the mid-19th century within the theatrical industry. It evolved from the phrase 'to draw an audience' (pulling people in). By the late 1800s, 'draw' became a noun for a spectacle that successfully attracted high ticket sales.

content.phrase: A bull in a china shop

meanings.english: An extremely awkward, clumsy person; someone who deals with a delicate situation roughly.
meanings.hindi: शीशे के घर में सांड (अनारी या बेढंगा व्यक्ति)।

content.usage: You can't let him manage the delicate negotiations; he behaves like a bull in a china shop.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'China' refers to fragile porcelain plates. Visual: Picture a massive, muscular Bull trying to turn around in a tiny shop filled with delicate glass and plates. Crash! Connect the dots: It describes someone reckless or clumsy in a situation requiring great care.
extras.origin: Popularized in early 19th-century political cartoons (often caricaturing John Bull or Napoleon). It serves as a visual metaphor for destructive energy unleashed in a fragile environment.

meanings.english: Someone who seems unfriendly and who does not share feelings.
meanings.hindi: भावनाहीन व्यक्ति; जो रूखा व्यवहार करे।

content.usage: I tried to be nice to him, but he's such a cold fish that he barely smiled back.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Fish are cold-blooded creatures. Visual: Imagine going for a warm hug but embracing a wet, dead fish instead. It feels slippery, chilly, and lifeless. Connect the dots: A 'cold fish' is a human who lacks warmth, emotion, and friendliness.
extras.origin: Used in Shakespeare's *The Winter's Tale*, but popularized in 20th-century slang. It draws on the biological fact that fish are cold-blooded to metaphorically describe an unemotional human.

meanings.english: Superior to; significantly better than others.

content.usage: Her presentation was a cut above the rest, earning her the promotion.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Cut' refers to a level or slice. Visual: Think of a butcher slicing meat or a jeweler cutting gems. The 'top cut' is always the most expensive and highest quality. Connect the dots: Being 'a cut above' means you are on a higher level of quality than the competition.
extras.origin: Most likely derived from 18th-century tiered grading systems, either for cuts of meat (where upper cuts are better) or the grading of gemstones based on their cut and clarity.

meanings.english: A disappointment result; something that is expected to be exciting but fails.

content.usage: The party was supposed to be the event of the year, but it turned out to be a damp squib.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: A 'Squib' is a small firecracker. Visual: You light a firework expecting a loud 'BOOM', but because the powder is damp (wet), it just makes a sad 'pffft' sound. Connect the dots: A situation that promises excitement but fails to deliver is a damp squib.
extras.origin: Mid-19th century. Originally, a 'squib' was a small explosive device used in mining or fireworks. If the gunpowder got wet, it failed to ignite properly.

meanings.english: A total mess; something done very badly.

content.usage: He made a dog's breakfast of the accounts; the numbers are all wrong.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Dogs eat messy leftovers. Visual: Look at a dog's food bowl—it's a chaotic mix of meat, gravy, and biscuits, all mushy and unorganized. Connect the dots: If a project looks like that bowl of mush, it's a 'dog's breakfast' (a total mess).
extras.origin: British slang from the 1930s. It originally alluded to a 'dog's dinner' or 'breakfast' being a chaotic mixture of scraps and leftovers.

meanings.english: An unpleasant situation (usually used ironically/sarcastically).
meanings.hindi: अजीब स्थिति (व्यंग्यात्मक रूप से एक बुरी स्थिति)।

content.usage: The car won't start and it's raining—this is a fine state of affairs!

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Fine' usually means good, but tone matters. Visual: Imagine standing in the pouring rain with a flat tire, rolling your eyes and saying, 'Well, this is just great.' Connect the dots: It is sarcasm; you say 'fine' to highlight how terrible the mess actually is.
extras.origin: Records date back to the 17th century. It relies on irony, where a positive word ('fine') is used to describe a chaotic or problematic situation.

meanings.english: A man without a job; a person who is free and has no specific occupation.
meanings.hindi: बेरोजगार व्यक्ति या ऐसा व्यक्ति जिस पर कोई जिम्मेदारी न हो।

content.usage: Since losing his position at the bank, he has been a gentleman at large.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'At large' means free or unconfined. Visual: Visualize a gentleman wandering the parks during work hours because he has nowhere to be. Connect the dots: He is 'at large' (free) from the confinement of a job or responsibility.
extras.origin: Historically, 'at large' meant having the liberty to go wherever one pleased. In the 19th century, it described wealthy men with no need to work; today, it implies unemployment.

meanings.english: A controversial situation or issue that is awkward to deal with.

content.usage: The issue of tax reform is a political hot potato that no one wants to touch.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Literal hot food. Visual: Imagine taking a potato straight out of a fire. It burns your hands! You have to toss it to someone else immediately or drop it. Connect the dots: A controversial topic burns you socially/politically, so you try to pass it on quickly.
extras.origin: Mid-19th century. Derived from the physical necessity of dropping or tossing a cooked potato that is too hot to hold comfortably.

meanings.english: An insecure scheme; a structure or plan that is very weak and likely to collapse.
meanings.hindi: ताश का घर (अत्यंत कमजोर योजना जो कभी भी गिर सकती है)।

content.usage: Without proper funding, the new business project is just a house of cards.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: A house made of playing cards. Visual: You delicately stack cards into a triangle tower. One small breath or a tiny shake of the table, and the whole thing collapses instantly. Connect the dots: A plan with no solid foundation is just as fragile.
extras.origin: Dates back to the 18th century, referring to the pastime of building structures with playing cards, which are notoriously unstable and temporary.

meanings.english: A grave setback; damaging treatment or a humiliating disappointment.

content.usage: Losing the contract after all that hard work was a real kick in the teeth.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Physical assault. Visual: Imagine the shock and pain of actually getting kicked in the mouth. It hurts, it's surprising, and it destroys your smile. Connect the dots: A sudden, painful setback that humiliates you feels exactly like that physical blow.
extras.origin: Found in the Bible (Proverbs) regarding broken teeth, but the modern idiom evolved in the 20th century to describe a sudden, damaging blow to one's hopes.

meanings.english: A period of poor performance or lack of success.

content.usage: The cricket team is going through a lean patch, having lost five games in a row.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Lean' means thin or lacking fat/resources. Visual: Think of a cow that hasn't eaten; it looks lean and weak. Or a garden patch with no vegetables growing. Connect the dots: A 'lean patch' in life is a time when 'harvest' (success) is thin and scarce.
extras.origin: Agricultural origin referring to a 'lean harvest' or 'lean years' (as in the Biblical story of Joseph), later adopted into sports commentary.

meanings.english: Used to indicate that the speaker knows something but chooses to keep the identity of their informant secret.
meanings.hindi: उड़ती-उड़ती खबर मिलना (गुप्त सूत्र से पता चलना)।

content.usage: A little bird told me that you are planning to resign next month.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Birds travel everywhere unnoticed. Visual: Imagine a tiny sparrow sitting on a window sill, overhearing a secret, then flying to you and whispering it in your ear. Connect the dots: It's a playful way to say 'I have a secret source' without naming them.
extras.origin: Biblical reference (Ecclesiastes 10:20): 'For a bird of the air shall carry the voice.' Also appears in John Heywood’s proverbs (1546).

meanings.english: A man of no substance; a weak person; an imaginary opponent created to be easily defeated.
meanings.hindi: कमजोर व्यक्ति; जिसका कोई प्रभाव न हो।

content.usage: The opposition leader was just a man of straw, easily defeated in the debate.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Straw is light and hollow. Visual: Imagine a Scarecrow. It looks like a man, but if you punch it, it falls over because it has no bones or muscles. Connect the dots: A 'man of straw' is a person with no backbone, substance, or power.
extras.origin: Refers to a scarecrow or 'straw man' used for combat practice. It implies a fake or weak opponent that is easily knocked down.

meanings.english: A disputed matter; a point that is open to debate but often irrelevant.

content.usage: Whether he would have won if he hadn't fallen is a moot point now.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Moot' historically meant a meeting. Visual: Imagine a law school 'Moot Court' where students argue hypothetical cases that have no real-world verdict. Connect the dots: A moot point is something debatable but ultimately practical value because the situation has passed.
extras.origin: From Old English 'gemot' (meeting/assembly). A 'moot' was a discussion assembly. Later, 'moot courts' were practice sessions for law students.

meanings.english: A fool; a naive person.

content.usage: Stop acting like a nig-nog and pay attention to the road.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Sounds childish and silly. Visual: Think of a cartoon character tripping over their own feet. Connect the dots: It implies someone acting foolishly. *Warning: Though historically meaning 'fool', it sounds close to offensive slurs, so avoid using it.*
extras.origin: British slang from the mid-20th century. Originally meant a foolish person or a raw recruit, but fell out of use due to phonetic similarity to racial slurs.

meanings.english: An endless job; a task that never seems to finish.
meanings.hindi: कभी न खत्म होने वाला काम।

content.usage: Cleaning this huge mansion feels like a Penelope's web; as soon as I finish one room, another gets dirty.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Penelope wove a cloth. Visual: Penelope weaving a shroud all day, but secretly unraveling it every night so she never finishes. Connect the dots: If you undo your work every night, the job is endless. That is a Penelope's web.
extras.origin: From Homer's *Odyssey*. Penelope, waiting for Odysseus, promised to remarry only when she finished weaving a shroud, but she unpicked her work nightly to delay.

meanings.english: A way of asking someone what they are thinking.

content.usage: You've been quiet for an hour. A penny for your thoughts?

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Purchasing information. Visual: You see someone lost in deep thought. You hold out a coin (penny) and say, 'I'll buy that thought from you.' Connect the dots: It's a gentle, polite bribe to get someone to share their silence.
extras.origin: 16th-century England (recorded by John Heywood). A penny was a decent sum then, making it a polite offer to value someone's thoughts.

meanings.english: Time of difficulty; a future time of financial need.
meanings.hindi: कठिन समय (विशेषकर जब पैसों की कमी हो)।

content.usage: You should save some salary for a rainy day.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Rain stops work. Visual: Imagine a farmer who can't work in the fields because of a storm. He earns no money that day. Connect the dots: He needs saved food/money to survive the storm. 'Rainy day' = Hard times when you need savings.
extras.origin: Dates back to the 16th century. Since outdoor manual labor (farming) stopped during rain, 'rainy days' were times of zero income, requiring savings.

meanings.english: An encouragement; a stimulus that restores energy or confidence.

content.usage: The new investment was a real shot in the arm for the struggling company.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Shot' means an injection. Visual: Imagine a tired runner getting a vitamin injection (shot) in the arm. Suddenly, they have a burst of energy! Connect the dots: Anything (money, praise) that gives a sudden boost of energy is a 'shot in the arm'.
extras.origin: Early 20th century. A metaphor drawn from medicine, referring to a hypodermic injection of a stimulant or drug to revive a patient.

meanings.english: An obstinate or haughty person; stubborn.

content.usage: He is such a stiff-necked person that he refuses to listen to anyone's advice.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Physical inability to bow. Visual: If your neck is stiff, you cannot bow your head in agreement or humility. You are stuck looking straight ahead. Connect the dots: This physical stiffness represents a mental refusal to agree or submit to others.
extras.origin: Biblical origin (Psalms 75:5). The Israelites were often described as 'stiff-necked' for refusing to bow to God's will.

meanings.english: A conservative, pompous, or self-important person.

content.usage: The new manager is a bit of a stuffed shirt; he cares more about rules than results.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Just the clothes, no human warmth. Visual: Imagine a formal shirt stuffed with straw or pillows. It looks fancy and stiff on the outside, but inside it's empty and lifeless. Connect the dots: Describes someone who is formal and pompous but lacks personality.
extras.origin: American slang from the early 20th century. It denotes a person who is stiff, formal, and pompous, like a display mannequin.

meanings.english: A difficult or much-debated issue.

content.usage: How to reduce traffic is a vexed question that the city council has debated for years.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Vex' means to annoy or worry. Visual: Imagine a puzzle that is so hard it makes you pull your hair out in frustration. Connect the dots: A 'vexed question' is a problem that annoys everyone because no one can find the answer.
extras.origin: From the Latin 'vexare' (to shake, disturb, or annoy). In the 19th century, it came to describe a topic that causes debate and trouble.

meanings.english: Water (unadulterated).

content.usage: He refused the wine and asked for a glass of Adam's ale.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Adam (First man) + Ale (Drink). Visual: Think of Adam in the Garden of Eden. Did he have beer or wine? No. He only had the river to drink from. Connect the dots: Adam's drink was water.
extras.origin: 17th-century colloquialism. It refers to the biblical Adam, for whom water was the only available beverage.

meanings.english: To help someone to commit a crime.

content.usage: He was charged with conspiracy to aid and abet the bank robbers.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Aid' means Help. 'Abet' means Encourage (usually for bad things). Visual: One guy holding the ladder (Aid) while cheering 'Go steal it!' (Abet). Connect the dots: Helping and encouraging a criminal act.
extras.origin: Legal terminology. 'Abet' comes from Old French 'abeter' (to hound on/urge dogs to bite), implying urging someone into trouble.

meanings.english: In good health and active.

content.usage: Despite the rumors of his illness, he is alive and kicking.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Not dead (alive) and moving energetically (kicking). Visual: A baby inside the mother's womb. If it's kicking, it's a strong, healthy sign. Connect the dots: Someone who is 'kicking' is full of life and energy.
extras.origin: Originally referred to pregnancy (when the baby begins to kick). Later expanded to mean anyone showing vigorous health and activity.

meanings.english: Amazed; in a state of high excitement or curiosity.

content.usage: The village was all agog with the news of the celebrity's arrival.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Rhymes with 'Frog'. Visual: Imagine a frog with huge, bulging eyes looking at something interesting. 'Agog' means your eyes are wide open with excitement. Connect the dots: To be 'all agog' is to be wide-eyed with curiosity.
extras.origin: Derived from the Old French 'en gogues', meaning 'in mirth' or 'lively'. The English adaptation emphasizes eagerness and wide-eyed anticipation.

meanings.english: Everyone included; all types of people.

content.usage: The invitation was open to all and sundry, so the hall was packed.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Sundry' means 'various items'. Visual: Imagine a bag of 'sundries' containing everything from pins to elephants. Connect the dots: 'All' (the group) + 'Sundry' (the individuals) = Absolutely everyone.
extras.origin: From Old English 'syndrig', meaning separate or distinct. The phrase combines the collective ('all') with the individual ('sundry').

meanings.english: One who is full of big talk but lacks substance and action.
meanings.hindi: बातें बड़ी, काम छोटा; केवल दिखावा।

content.usage: He promises great results, but I think he's all hat and no cattle.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Cowboy imagery. Visual: Picture a guy wearing a giant cowboy hat and boots, looking like a rancher. But look behind him—fields are empty. No cows. Connect the dots: He looks the part (All Hat) but has no wealth/substance (No Cattle).
extras.origin: Texan/American idiom. It mocks people who dress up as rich ranchers but actually own no livestock—essentially posers.

meanings.english: A metaphor for an abundance of acronyms and abbreviations that is confusing.

content.usage: The technical manual was just alphabet soup to me; I couldn't understand the codes.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Pasta letters. Visual: Look at a bowl of soup with pasta shaped like A, B, C floating randomly. Can you read a sentence? No, it's just jumbled letters. Connect the dots: A document full of confusing acronyms (NATO, NASA, FBI) looks like that soup.
extras.origin: Refers to the popular pasta soup for kids. Metaphorically applied to government agencies (the New Deal era) and bureaucratic language heavy with acronyms.

meanings.english: Someone who gives advice based on theory not practice; a person who critiques without actual experience.
meanings.hindi: आरामकुर्सी आलोचक (जो केवल सिद्धांत जानता हो, व्यवहार नहीं)।

content.usage: Ignore him; he's just an armchair critic who has never played football in his life.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Criticizing from comfort. Visual: Imagine a fat guy sitting in a soft armchair, eating chips, and yelling at professional athletes on TV telling them how to run. Connect the dots: He critiques without leaving his comfort zone or having experience.
extras.origin: 19th Century. Contrasts the comfort of home (the armchair) with the reality of action (travel, war, sports).

meanings.english: One of a number of resources or strategies that can be used to achieve a goal.
meanings.hindi: तर्कश में तीर (एक और उपाय या संसाधन)।

content.usage: Diplomacy is just another arrow in the quiver of the government's foreign policy.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Quiver' is a bag for arrows. Visual: An archer fighting a battle. He reaches back and pulls out another arrow. As long as he has arrows in the quiver, he has options to fight. Connect the dots: An arrow = A strategy/option available to use.
extras.origin: Archery terminology. A quiver is the container for arrows. Having 'another arrow' means having another resource ready to use.

meanings.english: Observant; vigilant; seeing everything.

content.usage: The teacher was Argus-eyed and caught the student cheating immediately.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Mythological monster. Visual: Imagine a giant with 100 eyes all over his body. Even if he sleeps, 50 eyes stay open. Nothing escapes his view. Connect the dots: Being 'Argus-eyed' means you see everything.
extras.origin: From Greek Mythology. Argus Panoptes was a giant with 100 eyes who was tasked by Hera to guard Io. He became the symbol of vigilance.

content.phrase: As bald as a cue ball

meanings.english: Completely bald.

content.usage: My uncle is as bald as a cue ball.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Pool game. Visual: Look at the white ball (cue ball) in pool/snooker. Is there any hair on it? No, it is perfectly round, smooth, and shiny. Connect the dots: A bald head that is shiny and hairless looks just like that ball.
extras.origin: Simile referencing billiard/pool balls, which are famously smooth and hairless.

meanings.english: Extremely silly or stupid.

content.usage: He's a nice guy, but he's as daft as a brush.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Inanimate object. Visual: Ask a cleaning brush a math question. It just sits there. It has no brain. Connect the dots: To be as smart as a brush is to be... well, stupid.
extras.origin: British colloquialism (mid-20th century). It might derive from 'soft as a brush' or refer to a 'brush tail' (fox), implying craziness.

meanings.english: Intoxicated with alcohol or drugs.

content.usage: He came home from the party as high as a kite.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'High' implies floating. Visual: A kite floats way up in the sky, detached from the ground, swaying in the wind. Connect the dots: A person on drugs feels 'high', floating above reality, just like that kite.
extras.origin: Originally meant simply 'high in altitude'. By the mid-20th century, 'high' became slang for intoxication, and the rhyme with 'kite' made it a popular idiom.

meanings.english: The shortest route; in a straight line.
meanings.hindi: एकदम सीधी दूरी (ना कि सड़क के रास्ते)।

content.usage: The town is ten miles away as the crow flies, but twenty miles by road.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Flight vs Walking. Visual: A crow flying from Point A to Point B goes in a straight line over forests and rivers. A human walking has to follow the winding roads. Connect the dots: The crow's path is the direct, shortest distance.
extras.origin: Based on the observation that birds (like crows) fly straight to their destination, ignoring ground obstacles.

content.phrase: As thick as two short planks

meanings.english: Extremely stupid.

content.usage: I tried explaining the math problem, but he's as thick as two short planks.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Thick' is slang for stupid. Visual: Imagine a short, chunky block of wood. It is dense, hard, and you can't get anything through it. Connect the dots: A person who is 'thick' has a brain like that wood—nothing penetrates it.
extras.origin: British slang. Wood is associated with stupidity (blockhead), and a 'short plank' is particularly dense and blocky.

meanings.english: Not attentive to one's duties; failing to attend to responsibilities.

content.usage: The security guard was asleep at the wheel when the theft occurred.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Driving metaphor. Visual: Imagine a bus driver falling asleep while holding the steering wheel. The bus is moving, but no one is controlling it! Disaster! Connect the dots: Failing to control a situation because you aren't paying attention.
extras.origin: Literal reference to driving. As cars became common, falling asleep while driving became a clear metaphor for neglecting responsibility.

meanings.english: Pretend superiority; to behave arrogantly.

content.usage: Since she got promoted, she has started to assume airs with her old friends.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: 'Airs' means looking above others. Visual: Imagine someone walking with their nose high in the 'air', refusing to look down at 'common' people. Connect the dots: To 'put on airs' is to act fake and superior.
extras.origin: From the French word 'air', meaning manner or appearance. To 'give oneself airs' meant to adopt a manner higher than one's true station.

meanings.english: Unable to decide; confused.

content.usage: I am at a loss to explain where the money went.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Losing your way. Visual: You are standing in the middle of a forest and your map flies away. You are 'at a loss' for direction. Connect the dots: Being mentally lost and not knowing what to say or do.
extras.origin: Originally a hunting term. When hounds lost the scent of their prey, they were 'at a loss' and ran around confused.

meanings.english: Always ready to obey someone's orders; at his disposal.
meanings.hindi: इशारों पर नाचना; सेवा में सदैव तत्पर।

content.usage: She expects her assistant to be at her beck and call 24 hours a day.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Beck (Gesture) + Call (Voice). Visual: A servant watching the master. The master gestures a finger (beckons) or shouts (calls), and the servant runs instantly. Connect the dots: To be ready to move the moment a signal is given.
extras.origin: 'Beck' is a shortened form of 'beckon' (to signal with a hand). Combined with 'call', it implies complete subservience to visual or vocal commands.

meanings.english: Enemies; in a state of open hostility.

content.usage: The two neighbors have been at daggers drawn ever since the property dispute.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Weapons out. Visual: Two enemies standing face-to-face. They haven't attacked yet, but they both have their knives (daggers) pulled out (drawn) and pointed. Connect the dots: The tension right before a fight; bitter hostility.
extras.origin: 17th Century. Refers to the moment before a physical fight starts, implying readiness to kill or harm.

meanings.english: Arguing angrily; fighting vehemently.
meanings.hindi: एक दूसरे के खून का प्यासा (लड़ना)।

content.usage: They used to be friends, but now they are at each other's throats.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Animal attack. Visual: Two wolves fighting. They don't bite the leg; they go straight for the throat to kill. Connect the dots: Humans arguing so viciously it looks like they want to strangle each other.
extras.origin: Animalistic metaphor describing violent aggression, where predators attack the throat to subdue prey quickly.

meanings.english: A criminal escaped or not yet captured; generally free.

content.usage: The prisoner escaped yesterday and is still at large.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Large means 'wide space'. Visual: Imagine a criminal running in a huge open field (a large space) rather than sitting in a tiny prison cell. Connect the dots: If you have 'large' room to roam, you are free/uncaptured.
extras.origin: Middle English. 'Large' originally meant 'liberal' or 'free range'. 'To go at large' meant to move freely without physical restraint.

meanings.english: In an uncertain situation; having nothing to do.

content.usage: After graduating, he felt a bit at loose ends regarding his career.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Unraveled rope. Visual: Look at the end of an old rope. If it isn't tied, the threads hang 'loose' and messy. It serves no purpose. Connect the dots: A person with no job or plan feels like that useless, unraveling rope end.
extras.origin: Nautical term. Ropes that were not 'whipped' (tied) at the ends would unravel and hang loose, requiring no specific work but needing attention.

meanings.english: In disorder or confusion.

content.usage: The whole office was at sixes and sevens after the manager resigned.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Confusing numbers. Visual: Imagine trying to organize files, but someone mixed up section 6 and section 7. Or imagine dice rolling 6s and 7s everywhere. Connect the dots: When things are mixed up and out of order, chaos ensues.
extras.origin: From an old dice game called 'Hazard'. Betting on 'five and six' or 'six and seven' was considered very risky. Later evolved to mean general confusion.

content.phrase: At the drop of a hat

meanings.english: Without any hesitation; instantly.

content.usage: She is ready to travel at the drop of a hat.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Starting signal. Visual: In the old days, a referee would hold a hat in the air. The moment he dropped it to the ground—GO! Everyone runs. Connect the dots: Doing something immediately upon the slightest signal.
extras.origin: 19th Century. Dropping a hat was a common, impromptu signal to start a race or a fight, implying immediate action.

content.phrase: At the top of your lungs

meanings.english: Extremely loud; shouting as loud as possible.
meanings.hindi: गला फाड़कर; पूरी ताकत से चिल्लाना।

content.usage: He shouted for help at the top of his lungs.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Lung capacity. Visual: Imagine your lungs as a tank. Use the air at the bottom? Quiet. Use all the air right to the 'top'? You produce a massive scream. Connect the dots: Maximum air = Maximum volume.
extras.origin: Anatomical metaphor. Using the full capacity of one's breathing apparatus to produce the loudest sound possible.

meanings.english: A young defenseless person; an innocent or inexperienced person in a dangerous situation.

content.usage: When it comes to politics, he is just a babe in the woods.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Infant in a forest. Visual: Imagine a toddler wandering alone in a dark, scary forest full of wolves. Connect the dots: The baby is innocent, helpless, and completely unaware of the dangers around it.
extras.origin: From the popular English ballad 'The Children in the Wood' (1595), where two children are left to die in a forest. It symbolizes innocence in peril.

meanings.english: Resume duty; to return to a position of control or responsibility.
meanings.hindi: काम पर लौटना; फिर से जिम्मेदारी संभालना।

content.usage: After a month of sick leave, he is finally back in the saddle.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Cowboy riding. Visual: A cowboy falls off his horse. He is on the ground (out of action). Then he climbs 'back in the saddle'. Connect the dots: He is now back in control of the horse and ready to work.
extras.origin: Equestrian/Cowboy terminology. Literally meaning to remount a horse after a fall or break, metaphorically applied to resuming work.

meanings.english: Plan it all over again; to start a failed project from the beginning.

content.usage: Our design failed the safety test, so it's back to the drawing board.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Architect's desk. Visual: An engineer draws a blueprint on a board. He builds it, but it explodes! What now? He walks back to his desk to draw a new plan. Connect the dots: Returning to the planning phase after failure.
extras.origin: Popularized by a Peter Arno cartoon in the *New Yorker* (1941). It depicted a crashed plane and a man walking away saying, 'Well, back to the old drawing board'.

meanings.english: Nonsensical talk; insincere flattery.
meanings.hindi: बकवास; चापलूसी या व्यर्थ की बातें।

content.usage: Don't listen to his excuses; it's just a lot of banana oil.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Slippery nonsense. Visual: Have you ever seen oil made from bananas? No, it doesn't exist! It's fake. Also, bananas are slippery. Connect the dots: Talk that is slippery, smooth, but ultimately fake/nonsense.
extras.origin: American slang from the 1920s ('flapper' era). 'Banana oil' was a synthetic solvent that smelled like bananas; the term came to mean something artificial or nonsensical.

meanings.english: More value for money; a good return on investment.
meanings.hindi: पैसे की पूरी कीमत; लागत का पूरा लाभ।

content.usage: This laptop offers the best bang for the buck in this price range.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Bang (Explosion) + Buck (Dollar). Visual: Buying fireworks. You want the biggest 'BANG' for your single dollar. Connect the dots: Getting the maximum result/impact for the money you spent.
extras.origin: US political/military slang from the 1950s/60s. Originally referred to the amount of destructive power (firepower) the military got for every dollar spent.

meanings.english: Prepare for a difficult situation.
meanings.hindi: मुश्किल हालात के लिए तैयार होना।

content.usage: A hurricane is coming, so we need to batten down the hatches.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Securing a ship. Visual: A storm is approaching a ship. Sailors rush to the deck openings (hatches) and nail wooden strips (battens) over them so water can't get in. Connect the dots: Getting ready to survive a coming storm/crisis.
extras.origin: Nautical origin. In bad weather, sailors used wooden battens and tarpaulins to seal the hatches to prevent the ship from flooding.

content.phrase: Be a dab hand at something

meanings.english: Skilled in a particular area; expert.
meanings.hindi: किसी काम में माहिर या निपुण।

content.usage: She is a dab hand at cooking Italian food.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Gentle touch. Visual: Imagine a painter or craftsman applying a tiny 'dab' of paint to finish a masterpiece perfectly. It requires a steady, expert hand. Connect the dots: Someone who can do things with such precision is an expert.
extras.origin: 19th Century British slang. 'Dab' implies someone who is adept. It might relate to 'dapping' (bouncing) or simply a corruption of 'adept'.

meanings.english: To be in serious trouble; likely to be punished or killed.
meanings.hindi: गंभीर मुसीबत में होना; काम तमाम हो जाना।

content.usage: If my dad finds out I broke the car, I am dead meat.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Lifeless flesh. Visual: Look at a steak in a butcher shop. It can't run, it can't fight, it's just 'dead meat'. Connect the dots: If you are in so much trouble that you have no escape, you are as helpless as that steak.
extras.origin: American slang. Implies that a person is as good as dead (or chopped meat) due to the consequences they face.

meanings.english: Make no difference; to be of no consequence.
meanings.hindi: कोई फर्क न पड़ना; एक समान होना।

content.usage: Whether we go by bus or train, it's all one to me.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: All options = One. Visual: You have three doors to choose from. Door 1, Door 2, Door 3. But they all lead to the exact same room. Connect the dots: If different choices lead to the same result, they are 'all one' to you.
extras.origin: Standard English idiom indicating indifference or equivalence between alternatives.

meanings.english: Suffering from an illness.

content.usage: He won't be at work today because he is down with the flu.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Lying down. Visual: When you are healthy, you stand up. When the flu hits you, you lose energy and have to lie 'down' in bed. Connect the dots: Being 'down' means being incapacitated by sickness.
extras.origin: Common usage referring to being laid low or incapacitated by sickness.

content.phrase: Be glad to see the back of

meanings.english: Be happy when a person leaves; relieved to be rid of someone/something.
meanings.hindi: किसी के जाने पर राहत महसूस करना।

content.usage: He was such a rude guest that I was glad to see the back of him.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Seeing them leave. Visual: When someone approaches you, you see their face. When they walk away, you see their back. Connect the dots: If you are happy to see their back, it means you are happy they are going away.
extras.origin: British idiom emphasizing the relief felt at someone's departure.

meanings.english: Talented and successful; likely to have a successful future.
meanings.hindi: तरक्की करना; सफल होने की राह पर।

content.usage: With her talent and work ethic, she is definitely going places.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Movement vs Stagnation. Visual: Most people stay in one spot. But this person is moving—going to the top, going to fame, going to wealth. Connect the dots: They are not stuck; they are moving toward success.
extras.origin: American colloquialism for upward mobility and future success.

meanings.english: To be in loss or debt.
meanings.hindi: घाटे में होना; कर्ज में होना।

content.usage: The company has been in the red for the last three quarters.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Accounting colors. Visual: Imagine an old ledger book. Profits are written in Black ink. Losses/Debts are written in Red ink (danger color). Connect the dots: If your account is 'in the red', you are losing money.
extras.origin: From bookkeeping conventions where negative balances were recorded in red ink to stand out.
