meanings.english: Afraid of speaking frankly; speaking vaguely or indirectly.
meanings.hindi: स्पष्ट बोलने से डरने वाला; गोलमोल बातें करने वाला।

content.usage: Politicians often give mealy-mouthed answers to difficult questions.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Mouth full of flour. Visual: Put a spoon of dry flour (meal) in your mouth. Try to speak. Can you speak clearly? No, it's soft, muffled, and messy. Connect the dots: Speaking indirectly or softly to avoid the truth.
extras.origin: 16th C. 'Meal' is a soft powder (like flour). A person who is 'mealy-mouthed' speaks soft, powdery words rather than hard, solid truths.

content.phrase: Nail your colours to the mast

meanings.english: To tell what you are thinking; to declare one's position defiantly.
meanings.hindi: अपना मत स्पष्ट करना; पीछे हटने से इनकार करना।

content.usage: During the debate, he nailed his colours to the mast and supported the controversial bill.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: No surrender. Visual: A pirate ship battle. Usually, if you lose, you lower your flag (colours). But the captain takes a hammer and nails the flag to the pole (mast). It *cannot* come down. Connect the dots: Refusing to surrender your opinion.
extras.origin: 18th C. Naval warfare. If a flag was shot away, it looked like surrender. Nailing it to the mast proved the crew would fight to the death.

meanings.english: No chance of success; a refusal.
meanings.hindi: कोई संभावना नहीं; सफलता न मिलना।

content.usage: I asked for a refund, but it was no dice.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Gambling failure. Visual: You want to play a game, but the casino boss says, 'No dice.' You can't roll, so you can't win. The game is off. Connect the dots: A definite no; nothing is happening.
extras.origin: Early 20th C. American slang. Often attributed to gambling, where a roll didn't count (no dice) or police seizing dice to stop an illegal game.

meanings.english: No one is self-sufficient; everyone relies on others.
meanings.hindi: कोई भी व्यक्ति अकेला नहीं रह सकता (समाज की जरूरत होती है)।

content.usage: You need to learn to work in a team because no man is an island.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Continent vs Island. Visual: An island stands alone in the sea, disconnected. Humans are like a continent—connected to the mainland. If one piece washes away, everyone feels it. Connect the dots: People are interconnected, not isolated.
extras.origin: From John Donne's meditation (1624): 'No man is an island, entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent.'

meanings.english: Tell your opinion clearly; to speak bluntly without softening the blow.

content.usage: The doctor did not mince matters and told him his condition was serious.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Whole meat. Visual: A chef has a piece of tough meat (truth). He can 'mince' it (chop it small) to make it easier to swallow. Or he can serve it whole and tough. Connect the dots: Not softening the hard truth.
extras.origin: 17th C. Culinary metaphor. To 'mince' means to chop into small pieces. Mincing words means making them smaller/softer to be polite. Not mincing means serving the raw truth.

meanings.english: Of the best quality.

content.usage: He is a diamond of the first water; honest and brilliant.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Diamond clarity. Visual: Look at a diamond. If it is as clear as pure spring water, it is perfect. If it's cloudy, it's cheap. Connect the dots: 'First water' means the highest level of purity and excellence.
extras.origin: 18th C. Gemology. Diamonds were graded by their translucency. The highest grade was 'first water', comparing the gem's clarity to a clear water droplet.

meanings.english: Without preparation; impromptu.

content.usage: He gave a brilliant speech right off the cuff.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Shirt notes. Visual: A speaker forgets his lines. He quickly glances at his shirt sleeve (cuff) where he scribbled some notes. He speaks from there. Connect the dots: Speaking with minimal or hasty preparation.
extras.origin: 1930s American slang. Refers to the habit of after-dinner speakers scribbling notes on their starched shirt cuffs at the last minute.

meanings.english: Out of trouble; no longer held responsible.
meanings.hindi: मुसीबत से मुक्त; जिम्मेदारी से बरी।

content.usage: Since they found the real thief, you are off the hook.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Freed fish. Visual: A fish is caught on a sharp metal hook. It wiggles and squirms until—pop!—it falls 'off the hook' and swims away safely. Connect the dots: Escaping a trap or responsibility.
extras.origin: Fishing. A fish that gets 'off the hook' has escaped being caught and eaten. Metaphorically applied to escaping trouble or blame.

meanings.english: On foot; walking.

content.usage: We missed the bus, so we had to go on Shank's mare.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Leg horse. Visual: 'Shank' is the bone in your lower leg. You don't have a real horse (mare), so you have to ride your own 'leg-horses'. Connect the dots: Walking because you have no vehicle.
extras.origin: 18th C. Scottish/British. A pun on 'shanks' (legs) and 'mare' (horse). Using one's own legs as a mode of transport.

meanings.english: On credit.

content.usage: He drank all night on the cuff and promised to pay later.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Sleeve tab. Visual: A bartender in the 1920s. A customer orders a drink but has no money. The bartender pencil-marks the debt on his stiff white cuff to remember it. Connect the dots: Putting it on a tab/credit.
extras.origin: 1920s. Similar to 'off the cuff', but here referring to bartenders jotting down a customer's debt on their starch cuffs.

meanings.english: Honest; truthful.

content.usage: Are you sure this deal is on the level?

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Flat surface. Visual: A carpenter puts a spirit level on a table. If the bubble is in the center, it is flat, straight, and perfect. If it tilts, it is 'crooked' (dishonest). Connect the dots: Straightforward and honest.
extras.origin: Freemasonry/Carpentry. A level ensures a structure is perfectly horizontal. Symbolically, it meant standing on an equal, honest plane of integrity.

meanings.english: Totally; completely (often used for negative things).

content.usage: That is an out and out lie!

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Inside and Out. Visual: Imagine something that is rotten. Not just on the inside, but 'out and out'—through every layer. Connect the dots: Thoroughly or completely (usually negative).
extras.origin: 14th C. Originally meant 'outwardly'. Evolved to mean 'thoroughly' or 'in every respect' (inside and out).

meanings.english: Poor; shabby.

content.usage: After losing his job, he was looking quite out at the elbows.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Worn clothes. Visual: Look at an old jacket. Where does it rip first? The bending point—the elbows. If your elbows are poking through your sleeves, you can't afford a new coat. Connect the dots: Poverty.
extras.origin: Refers to the condition of one's clothing. A coat worn until holes appear at the elbows indicates a lack of money to replace it.

meanings.english: Forbidden; outside the allowed area.

content.usage: The staff room is out of bounds for students.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Outside the lines. Visual: A football field has white lines. If the ball goes past them, the referee blows the whistle. STOP! You cannot play there. Connect the dots: An area where you are not allowed to go/act.
extras.origin: Sports/Geography. Refers to the boundaries of a playing field. Also refers to limits of school grounds for students.

meanings.english: Out of danger or difficulty.

content.usage: The patient is stable, but he is not out of the woods yet.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Forest danger. Visual: You are lost in a dark, scary forest (illness/danger). Finally, you see sunlight and an open field. You step out. You are safe. Connect the dots: Escaping a dangerous situation.
extras.origin: 18th C. American. The forest was a place of danger (beasts, getting lost). Emerging from the woods meant returning to safety/civilization.

meanings.english: Completely; deeply (usually in love or debt).

content.usage: He fell over head and ears in love with her.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Submerged. Visual: You jump into a deep pool. The water goes over your knees, then your chest, then over your ears and head. You are totally underwater. Connect the dots: Being completely immersed in a situation.
extras.origin: 16th C. Originally 'over head and heels'. It describes being physically submerged in deep water, metaphorically applied to love or debt.

meanings.english: To dispose off with the intent to deceive; to pass off something fake as real.

content.usage: The shopkeeper tried to palm off a fake watch on me.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Magic trick. Visual: A magician hides a card in his 'palm' so you can't see it. He hands you a different card. You've been tricked! Connect the dots: Trickily handing someone unwanted or fake goods.
extras.origin: 17th C. Sleight of hand (magic) or gambling. Cheaters would conceal dice or cards in their palms to swap them secretly.

meanings.english: A prolific source of trouble; a process that generates many complicated problems.

content.usage: Opening that investigation opened a Pandora's box of corruption charges.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Mythical curse. Visual: Pandora is given a beautiful box and told 'DO NOT OPEN'. Curiosity wins. She opens it. WHOOSH! Sickness, death, and misery fly out to plague the world. Connect the dots: Starting a process that releases uncontrollable trouble.
extras.origin: Greek Mythology. Pandora was the first woman. She opened a jar (later mistranslated as a box) releasing all evils into the world, leaving only Hope inside.

meanings.english: An unpleasant remark at the end of a conversation as one leaves.

content.usage: As he slammed the door, he fired a Parthian shot about her cooking.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Retreat attack. Visual: Ancient horse archers pretending to run away. As the enemy relaxes, the archers turn their bodies backward on the horse and shoot an arrow. Surprise hit! Connect the dots: A final insult delivered while leaving.
extras.origin: Historical military tactic of the Parthians (ancient Iran). They were famous for shooting arrows backward while retreating on horseback.

meanings.english: Very similar; indistinguishable.

content.usage: Those twins are like two peas in a pod.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Green twins. Visual: Open a green pea pod. Inside are 5 little green balls. They are round, green, and exactly the same size. You can't tell which is which. Connect the dots: People who are identical in looks or thought.
extras.origin: 16th C. Nature metaphor. Since peas within a single pod are virtually identical, they became the standard for similarity.

meanings.english: Analyse critically; to find many faults with.
meanings.hindi: बाल की खाल निकालना; कड़ी आलोचना करना।

content.usage: The critics picked his new novel to pieces.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Destructive analysis. Visual: A bird pecking at a piece of bread until it is just crumbs. Or a child taking a toy apart piece by piece until it's broken. Connect the dots: Criticizing something so much it is destroyed.
extras.origin: Likely related to 'picking apart' fabric or a mechanism to find faults or destroy it.

meanings.english: Something not possible; an illusory promise of future happiness.

content.usage: His plans for a Mars colony are just pie in the sky right now.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Floating dessert. Visual: You are hungry. Someone points up and says, 'There is a delicious pie floating in the clouds! You can eat it when you die.' It's not real food you can eat now. Connect the dots: Illusory promises.
extras.origin: From a 1911 song 'The Preacher and the Slave' by Joe Hill. It criticized preachers who promised starving workers 'pie in the sky when you die' instead of food now.

meanings.english: Hunt for a job on the street; to walk the streets looking for work.
meanings.hindi: नौकरी की तलाश में दर-दर भटकना।

content.usage: He has been pounding the pavement for months looking for a job.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Heavy walking. Visual: Imagine walking so much and so hard that your feet strike the concrete sidewalk (pavement) like hammers. *Pound, pound, pound.* Connect the dots: Walking extensively in the city to find work.
extras.origin: 20th C. American. Refers to the physical act of walking on concrete sidewalks (pavements) door-to-door.

meanings.english: To trick someone; to deceive.

content.usage: Don't try to pull a fast one on me; I know what you're up to.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Speed trick. Visual: A street magician moves his hands super fast. Before you blink, your wallet is gone! He moved too fast for you to see the trick. Connect the dots: Deceiving someone with a quick, clever trick.
extras.origin: Early 20th C. American slang. Likely from sports (a fast ball) or gambling (sleight of hand), implying a move too quick to be detected.

meanings.english: To use personal influence to get something done.
meanings.hindi: जुगाड़ लगाना; प्रभाव का इस्तेमाल करना।

content.usage: He got the job because his father pulled some strings.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Puppet master. Visual: A marionette puppet hangs limp. The puppeteer above 'pulls a string', and the puppet dances. Connect the dots: The person pulling the strings is the secret power controlling the situation.
extras.origin: 19th C. Metaphor from puppetry (marionettes), where the operator controls the doll's actions from above using strings.

meanings.english: To calm oneself down; to regain control of emotions.

content.usage: Stop crying and pull yourself together!

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Assemble pieces. Visual: Imagine you have shattered into pieces like a broken vase because of stress. Now, grab all those pieces and 'pull them together' to become whole again. Connect the dots: Regaining composure.
extras.origin: 19th C. Metaphor for mental stability. A composed person is 'together'; an emotional wreck is 'falling apart'.

meanings.english: Tolerate; to endure.

content.usage: I cannot put up with this noise any longer.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Hosting annoyance. Visual: An annoying relative comes to stay. You have to 'put them up' (give them a bed/food) in your house. It's annoying, but you do it. Connect the dots: Enduring something unpleasant.
extras.origin: Phrasal verb. 'To put up' meant to lodge or house someone. Housing someone difficult required tolerance.

meanings.english: Meet accidentally.

content.usage: I ran into my old teacher at the supermarket.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Physical collision. Visual: You are running around a corner and *BUMP*! You crash right into an old friend. Connect the dots: Meeting someone unexpectedly, as if by collision.
extras.origin: Phrasal verb. Evolved from the literal meaning of colliding with an obstacle.

meanings.english: Act without restraint; to grow or behave uncontrollably.

content.usage: The weeds have run riot in the garden.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Wild chase. Visual: A pack of hunting dogs smells a rabbit instead of a fox. They go crazy, barking and running everywhere, ignoring the hunter's whistle. Connect the dots: Behaving wildly and uncontrollably.
extras.origin: Hunting term. When hounds lost the intended scent and ran wildly after any random animal, they were said to 'run riot'.

meanings.english: Face negative consequences of one's actions.

content.usage: The government ignored the protests, and now they are reaping the whirlwind.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Storm harvest. Visual: A farmer plants 'wind' seeds. When harvest time comes, he doesn't get corn; he gets a destructive tornado (whirlwind) that destroys his farm. Connect the dots: Small bad actions leading to a huge disaster.
extras.origin: Biblical (Hosea 8:7): 'For they have sown the wind, and they shall reap the whirlwind.'

meanings.english: To revive forgotten quarrels; to bring up old bad memories.

content.usage: Let's not rip up old sores; we need to move forward.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Re-opening wounds. Visual: You have a scab on your knee from an old fall. It's healing. Then you scratch (rip) it off. It bleeds and hurts all over again. Connect the dots: Bringing up old pain.
extras.origin: Medical metaphor. Disturbing a healing wound causes fresh pain, just as mentioning old arguments causes fresh anger.

meanings.english: Completely; destroying something totally.

content.usage: The new manager decided to reorganize the company root and branch.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Whole tree. Visual: You don't just cut the leaves of a weed. You pull it out by the *roots* and burn the *branches*. Nothing is left. Connect the dots: Total destruction or transformation.
extras.origin: Biblical (Malachi 4:1). 'It shall leave them neither root nor branch.' A metaphor for complete destruction of a tree/family line.

meanings.english: A positive outlook on life; seeing things as better than they are.

content.usage: He looks at the world through rose-coloured glasses and refuses to see the danger.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Pink tint. Visual: Put on sunglasses with pink lenses. Suddenly, the grey, gloomy sky looks warm and rosy. The trash on the street looks artistic. Connect the dots: Seeing a better version of reality than what exists.
extras.origin: Victorian literature (e.g., *Tom Brown at Oxford*, 1861). Refers to an optimistic perception that makes unpleasant things look attractive.

meanings.english: Adolescence; time of youth and inexperience.
meanings.hindi: जवानी के दिन; अनुभवहीनता का दौर।

content.usage: He often talks about his salad days when he was a struggling artist.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Green youth. Visual: Salad is made of fresh, green vegetables. Being 'green' means being young and inexperienced. Connect the dots: The days when you were young, fresh, and 'green' (inexperienced).
extras.origin: Shakespeare's *Antony and Cleopatra*. Cleopatra refers to her youth as: 'My salad days, When I was green in judgment'.

meanings.english: Deal firmly with a difficulty.

content.usage: We need to seize the nettle and solve this debt problem now.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Plant handling. Visual: A nettle is a plant with stinging hairs. If you touch it gently, it stings you. If you grab (seize) it hard and crush it instantly, the thorns break and don't hurt. Connect the dots: Tackling a problem boldly creates less pain.
extras.origin: From an old proverb (1500s): 'Grasp the nettle and it won't sting you.' Popularized by Aaron Hill's poem (1750).

meanings.english: To get rid of something bad (like a cold or a bad habit).

content.usage: I can't seem to shake off this cold.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Wet dog. Visual: A dog falls in a river. It gets out and 'shakes' its body violently. Water droplets fly everywhere. The dog is dry again. Connect the dots: Getting rid of something unwanted.
extras.origin: Physical action metaphor. Literally shaking oneself to dislodge dust, water, or attachments.

meanings.english: Very easy task.
meanings.hindi: बाएं हाथ का खेल; बहुत आसान काम।

content.usage: The quiz was so easy, it was like shooting fish in a barrel.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: No escape. Visual: Fish usually swim in a huge ocean. Hard to catch. Now put them in a small wooden barrel. They are trapped. Even a bad shooter can hit them. Connect the dots: An impossibly easy task.
extras.origin: American slang. The confined space of a barrel makes it impossible for the fish to escape, ensuring success for the shooter.

meanings.english: A simple solution to a complicated problem.

content.usage: There is no silver bullet for climate change; it requires many different solutions.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Monster killer. Visual: A village is terrorized by a werewolf. Normal guns don't work. You need one special thing: a bullet made of silver. BANG! The monster dies instantly. Connect the dots: A magical, instant solution.
extras.origin: Folklore. In werewolf mythology, silver is the only substance that can kill the beast. In modern usage, it signifies a miraculous fix.

meanings.english: To wait before making a decision.
meanings.hindi: निर्णय लेने से पहले सोच-विचार करना (अगले दिन तक टालना)।

content.usage: Don't decide now; sleep on it and tell me your answer tomorrow.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Overnight thought. Visual: You have a big problem. You go to bed with the problem in your head. Your brain works while you sleep. You wake up with a clear answer. Connect the dots: Delaying a decision until the next day.
extras.origin: Based on the ancient belief (and modern science) that the subconscious mind processes information during sleep, leading to better decisions in the morning.

meanings.english: Indifferent; aloof and unfriendly.

content.usage: She seems stand-offish, but she is actually just shy.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Keeping distance. Visual: A ship trying to dock, but it 'stands off' (keeps distance) from the shore because of rocks. It refuses to come close. Connect the dots: A person who refuses to get close to others.
extras.origin: Nautical term. A ship that 'stands off' maintains a distance from the shore or another vessel. Applied to human behavior metaphorically.

meanings.english: Complete halt; a state of no movement.

content.usage: Traffic came to a standstill due to the accident.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Standing still. Visual: Imagine a busy factory. Suddenly, the power cuts. All machines stop. Workers stop moving. Everyone is 'standing still'. Connect the dots: A total stop.
extras.origin: Compound word. Literally combining 'stand' and 'still' to describe a state of total lack of movement.

meanings.english: An indication of what might happen; a sign of future trends.

content.usage: The small protest was just a straw in the wind representing larger unrest.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Wind detector. Visual: You want to know which way the wind blows, but you have no flag. You toss a light piece of straw into the air. It flies East. Now you know. Connect the dots: A small sign indicating a larger trend.
extras.origin: From the proverb: 'A straw will show which way the wind blows'. Used by John Selden (17th C.) to explain how small signs reveal big trends.

meanings.english: Pride; conceited.
meanings.hindi: घमंडी; जिसका दिमाग सातवें आसमान पर हो।

content.usage: Success has made him swollen headed; he won't talk to his old friends.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Big head. Visual: A cartoon character gets praised. His head literally inflates like a balloon because it's full of hot air and ego. It gets so big he can't fit through the door. Connect the dots: Having a huge ego.
extras.origin: Colloquial. Related to 'big-headed'. Physical swelling implies an excess of self-importance filling the cranium.

meanings.english: To object strongly; to be offended by.

content.usage: I take exception to your comment that I am lazy.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Rejecting inclusion. Visual: Someone lists facts: 'Sun is hot, water is wet, you are stupid.' You stop them: 'I accept the first two, but I make an EXCEPTION for the last one.' Connect the dots: Objecting to a specific statement.
extras.origin: Legal terminology. In court, a lawyer 'takes exception' to a judge's ruling, formally registering an objection.

meanings.english: To take courage; to feel encouraged.

content.usage: Take heart, things will get better soon.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Grab courage. Visual: Imagine 'heart' is a physical glowing orb of bravery. You are scared (empty). Someone hands you the orb. You 'take' it into your chest. Now you feel brave. Connect the dots: To gain courage/hope.
extras.origin: Old English/Biblical. The heart was considered the seat of spirit and courage. To 'lose heart' is to be discouraged; to 'take heart' is to regain it.

meanings.english: Prepare to go to war.

content.usage: The tribes decided to take up the hatchet to defend their land.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Digging up weapons. Visual: A peace treaty ends, and war begins. The warriors go to the spot where they buried their weapons (hatchets) for peace. They dig them up. Connect the dots: Resuming fighting.
extras.origin: Native American custom. The opposite of 'burying the hatchet'. When peace ended, the weapon was dug up for war.

meanings.english: Similar to (usually a parent or relative).
meanings.hindi: शक्ल या स्वभाव में मिलना (अपने बड़ों जैसा होना)।

content.usage: She takes after her mother in her love for music.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Following path. Visual: A duckling walking behind a mother duck. It walks the same, quacks the same. It is 'taking' the path 'after' the mother. Connect the dots: Resembling an ancestor.
extras.origin: Phrasal verb. To follow an example or resemble a predecessor.

meanings.english: Majority of votes are in favour.
meanings.hindi: प्रस्ताव के पक्ष में बहुमत होना।

content.usage: The Speaker announced, 'The ayes have it', and the bill was passed.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Aye = Yes. Visual: A room full of pirates voting. 'Who wants gold?' Everyone shouts 'AYE!' The volume of the 'Ayes' is louder than the 'Nos'. Connect the dots: The 'Yes' side wins.
extras.origin: Parliamentary procedure (UK/US). 'Aye' is an archaic word for 'Yes'. Used in voice votes to declare the winning side.

meanings.english: Extraordinary; outstandingly good.

content.usage: He thinks his new motorcycle is the bee's knees.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Silly rhyme. Visual: Imagine a bee wearing tiny, cool sunglasses and shiny shoes on its knees. It looks awesome and ridiculous. Connect the dots: Old slang for 'The Best'.
extras.origin: 1920s American slang. Part of a fad for nonsense animal phrases like 'the cat's pajamas'. Also, bees carry sweet pollen on their legs (knees), implying something sweet/good.

meanings.english: The decision has been taken and cannot be changed.
meanings.hindi: फैसला हो चुका है (अब पीछे नहीं हटो जा सकता)।

content.usage: We have signed the contract; the die is cast.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Thrown dice. Visual: You are gambling. You throw the dice out of your hand. While they are in the air, you cannot grab them back. You must accept whatever number lands. Connect the dots: Irreversible action.
extras.origin: Said by Julius Caesar ('Alea iacta est') upon crossing the Rubicon River with his army, initiating a civil war from which there was no turning back.

meanings.english: Big international bankers (specifically Swiss bankers).
meanings.hindi: स्विस बैंकर (जो गुप्त रूप से धन रखते हैं)।

content.usage: The Gnomes of Zurich were blamed for the currency crisis.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Wealth guardians. Visual: Fairy tales have Gnomes—small creatures living underground guarding piles of gold. Swiss bankers have huge underground vaults full of gold. Connect the dots: Secretive bankers guarding wealth.
extras.origin: Coined by British Labour politician Harold Wilson in 1956. He accused Swiss bankers of speculating against the British pound.

meanings.english: The most important aspect or practical details of a subject.

content.usage: Let's stop dreaming and get down to the nitty-gritty of the business plan.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Grit = Sand. Visual: To clean something perfectly, you have to scrub out the tiny specs of dirt ('nits') and sand ('grit'). You are dealing with the rough, basic reality. Connect the dots: The essential, practical details.
extras.origin: Debated. Possibly refers to the debris (nits) and sand (grit) found in grain, or simply a rhyming compound for detailed, unpleasant realities.

meanings.english: The unpleasant, immoral, or rough aspect of life.
meanings.hindi: जीवन का घिनौना या अनैतिक पहलू।

content.usage: As a police officer, he sees the seamy side of the city every night.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Wrong side of cloth. Visual: A beautiful dress looks perfect on the outside. Turn it inside out. You see the 'seams'—messy stitching, loose threads, and knots. Connect the dots: The ugly reality hidden behind a nice appearance.
extras.origin: Shakespeare's *Othello*. Referring to the wrong side of a garment where the rough seams are visible, representing the rough/immoral side of life.

meanings.english: Start of a harmful development; a small change that leads to bigger problems.

content.usage: Ignoring minor rule violations is the thin end of the wedge for total lawlessness.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Splitting wood. Visual: A wedge is a tool shaped like a triangle (thin tip, thick back). You tap the *thin end* into a log easily. Once it's in, you hammer the thick end, and it splits the whole tree apart. Connect the dots: A small start causing a huge split.
extras.origin: Mechanical metaphor. A wedge is a simple machine used to split heavy objects. The thin end enters easily, but the result is a massive separation.

meanings.english: Things starting to go wrong; a situation failing completely.
meanings.hindi: गाड़ी पटरी से उतर जाना; सब कुछ बिगड़ जाना।

content.usage: The project was going well until the funding stopped, and then the wheels came off.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Broken vehicle. Visual: A car speeding down the highway. Suddenly—CLUNK!—all four wheels roll away. The car crashes and sparks fly. It cannot move. Connect the dots: A system or plan failing catastrophically.
extras.origin: Vehicle metaphor. When the wheels detach from a cart or car, the journey ends instantly in disaster.

meanings.english: To prevent a plan from succeeding; to sabotage.
meanings.hindi: रंग में भंग डालना; काम बिगाड़ना।

content.usage: The sudden rain threw a spanner in our picnic plans.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Jamming gears. Visual: A complex machine with gears spinning perfectly. Someone throws a heavy metal wrench (spanner) into the gears. *CRUNCH*. The machine stops and breaks. Connect the dots: Sabotaging a plan.
extras.origin: Industrial slang. A 'spanner' (UK) or 'monkey wrench' (US) thrown into machinery would wreck the gears and stop production.

meanings.english: To express hatred or disrespect; to show contempt.

content.usage: He thumbed his nose at the rules and did whatever he wanted.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Rude gesture. Visual: Put your thumb on the tip of your nose and wiggle your fingers at someone. It's a childish way of saying 'Nyah nyah, I don't care about you.' Connect the dots: Showing disrespect.
extras.origin: Physical gesture known as 'cocking a snook' or 'Queen Anne's Fan'. Used for centuries as a sign of mockery and contempt.

meanings.english: To surrender; to give up.

content.usage: After struggling for years, he finally threw up the sponge and closed the business.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Boxing surrender. Visual: In old boxing matches, coaches used a sponge to wipe blood from a fighter. If the fighter was losing badly, the coach threw the sponge into the air (or ring) to stop the fight. Connect the dots: Quitting.
extras.origin: 19th C. Boxing. A second (coach) would throw the sponge used for cleaning the boxer into the ring to signal resignation. Later replaced by 'throwing in the towel'.

meanings.english: For a long time; indefinitely.

content.usage: You can argue til the cows come home, but I won't change my mind.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Slow animals. Visual: Cows graze in the fields all day. They only walk back to the barn at night, and they walk extremely slowly. Waiting for them feels like forever. Connect the dots: A very long, indefinite time.
extras.origin: 16th C. Agricultural. Cows are let out to pasture in the morning and do not return for milking until the evening/night, usually taking their sweet time.

meanings.english: To fish; to try to get something indirectly.
meanings.hindi: मछली पकड़ना; घुमा-फिरा कर कुछ प्राप्त करने की कोशिश करना।

content.usage: He was angling for an invitation to the party.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Fishing hook. Visual: An 'angle' is an old word for a hook. You dangle a hook with bait to catch a fish. Similarly, you dangle hints to catch a compliment or invitation. Connect the dots: Fishing for something.
extras.origin: Old English. An 'angle' was a fish-hook. 'Angling' literally means fishing with a hook and line, metaphorically fishing for information/favors.

meanings.english: In a confusing situation; unsure what to do.

content.usage: I was in a quandary about which job offer to accept.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Quandary = Wandering. Visual: Imagine you are 'wandering' in a maze with two paths. You stand in the middle asking 'When? Where? Which?' You are stuck. Connect the dots: A state of mental confusion.
extras.origin: Derived from the Latin 'quando' meaning 'when'. It implies a state of uncertainty about when or how to act.

meanings.english: To be dead and buried.

content.usage: If I try to ride that motorcycle, I'll be pushing up daisies.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Underground gardening. Visual: You are buried in a grave. Above you, flowers (daisies) grow. Since you are underneath, you are metaphorically 'pushing' them up towards the sun. Connect the dots: Being dead and buried.
extras.origin: World War I slang. A humorous or euphemistic way to describe death, referencing flowers growing on soldiers' graves.

meanings.english: To be surprised or shocked.

content.usage: I was taken aback by his sudden rudeness.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Sails reversed. Visual: A ship sailing forward. Suddenly, a strong wind hits the sails from the front, pressing them 'back' against the mast. The ship stops dead in the water. Shocked. Connect the dots: A sudden, shocking halt.
extras.origin: Nautical term. When the wind suddenly shifts and blows the sails flat against the masts, the ship is 'taken aback' and stops abruptly.

meanings.english: To feel sick.

content.usage: I'm feeling a bit under the weather, so I'll stay home today.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Seasickness. Visual: On a ship, bad weather makes big waves. Passengers feel sick. To feel better, they go 'under' the deck, away from the weather. Connect the dots: Feeling sick or unwell.
extras.origin: Nautical. Sailors or passengers who were seasick during a storm would go below deck—literally 'under the weather'—to recover.

meanings.english: To run away in fear; to withdraw.

content.usage: When he saw the angry dog, he beat a hasty retreat.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Drum signal. Visual: In old wars, soldiers couldn't hear voice commands. A drummer boy would 'beat' a specific rhythm on his drum that meant 'Run away!' Connect the dots: Signaling and executing a withdrawal.
extras.origin: Military. Refers to the drum beat signal ordered by a commander to tell troops to withdraw from battle.

meanings.english: To be acquitted of a crime; to escape punishment.

content.usage: He hired a good lawyer and managed to beat the rap.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Fighting the charge. Visual: 'Rap' is slang for a criminal charge (rap sheet). Imagine fighting a boxing match against the 'Rap'. If you win (beat) it, you go free. Connect the dots: Escaping punishment.
extras.origin: American criminal slang (20th C.). 'Rap' meant a criminal accusation or prison sentence. 'Beating' it meant winning the court case.

meanings.english: To wish good luck (usually before a performance).

content.usage: Break a leg in your play tonight!

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Reverse psychology. Visual: Actors are superstitious. They believe wishing 'Good Luck' attracts demons. So they wish something terrible ('Break a leg!') to trick fate into giving them good luck. Connect the dots: Meaning good luck.
extras.origin: Theatrical superstition. Possible origins: 1) Bending the leg to bow/curtsey after applause. 2) German phrase 'Hals- und Beinbruch' (neck and leg break) used by pilots/actors.

meanings.english: To succeed; to win a victory.

content.usage: Despite strong opposition, his argument carried the day.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Winning the field. Visual: Two armies fighting all day. At sunset, one army is left standing. They 'carry' the victory of that specific day. Connect the dots: To win the contest.
extras.origin: Military. 'The day' refers to the day of battle (e.g., 'The day is ours!'). To carry it meant to dominate the event.

meanings.english: To remove obstructions; to prepare for action.

content.usage: We need to clear the decks before starting the new project.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Battle prep. Visual: A warship is about to fight. The sailors throw hammocks, tables, and luggage away so the cannons can move freely. They 'clear the deck' for action. Connect the dots: Removing clutter to get ready to work.
extras.origin: Naval. Before a sea battle, 'Clear for action' meant removing all unnecessary items from the deck to prevent fire hazards and allow gun crews to work.

meanings.english: To gain experience at a beginning stage.

content.usage: I cut my teeth on local reporting before moving to a national newspaper.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Baby teething. Visual: A baby's teeth push through gums (cutting). They chew on soft rubber toys to practice using their new teeth. Connect the dots: Your first practice job where you learned the basics.
extras.origin: Refers to the emergence of milk teeth in infants. Just as 'cutting teeth' is the first stage of growing up, this phrase refers to early professional development.

meanings.english: To stop talking and start working; stop talking nonsense.
meanings.hindi: बकवास बंद करना और काम पर लगना।

content.usage: Let's cut the cackle and get down to business.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Hens vs Horses. Visual: A hen house is noisy (cackle, cackle). A stable is for work (horses). 'Stop the bird noise and bring out the work animals!' Connect the dots: Stop chattering and start doing.
extras.origin: From the older phrase 'Cut the cackle and come to the 'osses (horses)', meaning stop the showman's speech and bring out the circus horses.

meanings.english: Come to know (usually a secret).

content.usage: I hope the press doesn't get wind of the scandal.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Scent on breeze. Visual: A deer is eating. Suddenly it freezes. It smells a wolf carried on the wind. It knows danger is coming before seeing it. Connect the dots: Hearing a rumor/secret before it is announced.
extras.origin: Hunting. Animals detect predators by their scent carried on the wind. To 'get wind' of something is to detect it via subtle clues.

meanings.english: To prepare for hard work or a difficult task.

content.usage: We must gird up our loins for the difficult journey ahead.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Tying up robes. Visual: In Bible times, men wore long robes. You can't run or fight in a dress! So, they tied (girded) the loose fabric up between their legs (loins) to move freely. Connect the dots: Preparing for action.
extras.origin: Biblical (Proverbs/1 Peter). Men wore tunics. To work or fight, they tucked the hem into their belt (girdle) to free their legs.

content.phrase: To go down like a lead balloon

meanings.english: A poorly received joke or idea; to fail completely.
meanings.hindi: बुरी तरह असफल होना (मजाक या प्रस्ताव का)।

content.usage: His joke went down like a lead balloon; nobody laughed.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Heavy airship. Visual: Balloons float because they are light. Imagine a balloon made of heavy lead metal. You let go, and *CRASH*! It falls straight to the floor. Connect the dots: A joke or idea that fails to fly (succeed).
extras.origin: Mid-20th C. Associated with the band Led Zeppelin (Keith Moon joked that a band would go down like a 'lead zeppelin/balloon').

meanings.english: To arrive at an agreement through discussion; to create a plan with effort.

content.usage: They spent hours trying to hammer out a peace treaty.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Blacksmith work. Visual: A lump of metal is shapeless. The blacksmith hits it with a hammer again and again—*CLANG, CLANG*—until it becomes a sword. Connect the dots: Working hard on a problem until it takes the right shape.
extras.origin: Blacksmithing metaphor. Shaping hot metal requires repeated heavy blows. Metaphorically applied to shaping an agreement through hard negotiation.

meanings.english: To have a very good time.

content.usage: We had a blast at the concert last night.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Explosion of fun. Visual: A cannon blast is loud, energetic, and shakes everything. A party that is 'a blast' is just as loud and energetic. Connect the dots: Having an explosive amount of fun.
extras.origin: US Slang (mid-20th C.). Originally referred to a strong gust of wind or an explosion, later applied to a thrill or exciting event.

meanings.english: To go to sleep.

content.usage: I'm exhausted; I'm going to hit the sack.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Old mattress. Visual: Before memory foam, poor people slept on cloth sacks stuffed with hay. When tired, you literally threw your body onto the sack. Connect the dots: Going to bed.
extras.origin: Late 19th C. American slang. Mattresses were often simple sacks filled with straw or hay.

meanings.english: To follow popular trends; to join a winning side.
meanings.hindi: बहती गंगा में हाथ धोना; देखा-देखी करना।

content.usage: Once the team started winning, everyone jumped on the bandwagon.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Parade wagon. Visual: A circus parade. The band plays music on a colorful wagon. It looks fun! Politicians would jump onto the wagon to be seen by the crowd. Connect the dots: Joining something just because it is popular.
extras.origin: 19th C. American politics. Politicians would literally ride on the circus bandwagon during parades to gain attention. Supporting a popular candidate meant 'getting on the bandwagon'.

meanings.english: In a state of suspension; temporarily inactive.
meanings.hindi: स्थगित रखना; कुछ समय के लिए रोक देना।

content.usage: The project was kept in abeyance until funding was secured.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Yawning gap. Visual: Imagine a title or property floating in a bubble, waiting for someone to claim it. It belongs to no one right now. It is paused. Connect the dots: Held in suspension.
extras.origin: Old French 'abeance' (gaping/yawning). Legal term. If a property had no current owner (waiting for an heir), it was 'in abeyance' (waiting).

meanings.english: To be in touch; to maintain the same pace.

content.usage: It is hard to keep up with the fast pace of technology.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Running alongside. Visual: Your friend is running fast. You run fast too to stay by his side. If you slow down, you fall behind. Connect the dots: Maintaining the same speed or standard.
extras.origin: Phrasal verb denoting maintaining position or pace alongside someone or something.

meanings.english: To make a lot of money.

content.usage: He made a pile investing in the stock market.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Stack of cash. Visual: Instead of a wallet, imagine stacking gold coins on the floor until you have a giant 'pile' reaching the ceiling. Connect the dots: Earning a huge amount of money.
extras.origin: Colloquial. Simply refers to a 'pile' or heap of money.

meanings.english: To stop something at the start before it grows.
meanings.hindi: पनपने से पहले ही नष्ट कर देना।

content.usage: Bad habits should be nipped in the bud.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Gardening pinch. Visual: A gardener sees a weed starting to grow. It is just a tiny bud. He pinches (nips) it off immediately. It never becomes a big plant. Connect the dots: Stopping a problem early.
extras.origin: Horticulture (Gardening). Removing buds prevents fruit/flowers from forming. Used metaphorically for stopping plans or habits early.

meanings.english: To take revenge; to settle a grudge.

content.usage: He is just trying to pay off old scores rather than solve the problem.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Settling the tab. Visual: In old pubs, debt was marked with scratches (scores) on wood. 'Paying off the score' meant clearing the debt. In a fight, it means clearing the debt of insults. Connect the dots: Getting revenge.
extras.origin: Tavern/Accounting. 'Score' referred to the tally marks on a stick or door to record debt. 'Settling the score' meant balancing the account.

meanings.english: To criticise someone; to find faults.

content.usage: It is easy to pick holes in someone else's work.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Ruining cloth. Visual: A piece of fabric looks fine. But a critic grabs a needle and starts 'picking' at the threads until they create a hole. 'Look! A hole!' Connect the dots: Deliberately finding or creating faults.
extras.origin: Textile metaphor. To 'pick a hole' in a piece of cloth (or an argument) creates a flaw or exposes weakness.

meanings.english: To restart from the previous closing point; to resume.
meanings.hindi: फिर से शुरू करना (जहां से छोड़ा था)।

content.usage: After the interruption, he tried to pick up the threads of his story.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Weaver's break. Visual: A weaver stops working. The loom stops. To start again, he must find the loose threads where he left off and tie them back in. Connect the dots: Resuming a story or life after a break.
extras.origin: Weaving/Spinning. If a thread broke or work paused, the spinner had to pick up the ends to join them and continue the pattern.

meanings.english: To unfairly categorize someone; to put aside for later.
meanings.hindi: खांचे में बांटना (सीमित करना); ठंडे बस्ते में डालना।

content.usage: Don't pigeon hole him as just a comedian; he is a great actor too.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Desk boxes. Visual: Old desks had grid slots for mail that looked like pigeon coops. You shoved papers into slots labeled 'Bills', 'Letters', etc. Connect the dots: Shoving a person into a specific category or putting an idea away.
extras.origin: Refers to 'pigeon-holes' in desks or post offices used for sorting mail. Putting something in a pigeon-hole meant filing it away or categorizing it rigidly.

meanings.english: To seek to win approval from the crowd; to perform for popularity.
meanings.hindi: जनता को खुश करने के लिए काम करना; वाहवाही लूटना।

content.usage: The politician was accusing of playing to the gallery instead of addressing real issues.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Cheap seats. Visual: In old theaters, the 'gallery' was the highest, cheapest section where the common people sat. They loved loud jokes and action. Connect the dots: Actors overacting to please the common crowd for cheers.
extras.origin: 17th C. Theater. The gallery housed the cheapest seats. Playing to them meant aiming for easy applause rather than artistic quality.

content.phrase: To put one out of countenance

meanings.english: To make one feel ashamed or disconcerted.

content.usage: The staring of the crowd put him out of countenance.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Lose face. Visual: 'Countenance' means your facial expression or composure. Imagine someone staring at you until you blush, look down, and lose your confident look. Connect the dots: To embarrass someone so they lose their composure.
extras.origin: Countenance (from French 'contenance') means bearing or facial expression. To be 'put out of' it means to have your composure disturbed.

meanings.english: Tolerate; to endure someone or something unpleasant.

content.usage: I cannot put up with his rude behavior anymore.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Hosting annoyance. Visual: A rude relative comes to visit. You have to 'put them up' (give them a bed and food) in your house. It is annoying, but you do it. Connect the dots: Enduring an unpleasant situation without quitting.
extras.origin: Phrasal verb. Originally 'to put up' meant to lodge or house someone. Housing a difficult person required patience and tolerance.

meanings.english: To run about in a frenzy; to behave uncontrollably.
meanings.hindi: आपा खोकर इधर-उधर भागना; उपद्रव मचाना।

content.usage: The cattle ran amok in the market, overturning stalls.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Warrior frenzy. Visual: A warrior in a trance charges through a village, swinging his sword wildly at everyone, friends or foes. He is unstoppable. Connect the dots: Behaving in a wild, uncontrolled frenzy.
extras.origin: Derived from the Malay word 'amuk'. It described a specific condition where a tribesman would go into a murderous frenzy, attacking anyone in his path.

meanings.english: To have a casual conversation; to chat aimlessly.
meanings.hindi: गपशप करना; हवा में बातें करना।

content.usage: We sat on the porch and shot the breeze for hours.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Targeting air. Visual: Two cowboys sitting on a fence with guns. They are bored, so they shoot at the wind (breeze) because there are no real targets. Connect the dots: Doing something pointless but relaxing (talking about nothing).
extras.origin: American slang (early 20th C). Refers to empty talk. Similar to 'shooting the bull' or 'hot air'—conversation with no substance.

meanings.english: To avoid deliberately; to reject.

content.usage: After the scandal, he was shunned by his former friends.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Turn away. Visual: Think of a vampire. What does he do to the Sun? He 'shuns' it (turns away/avoids) because it burns him. Shun sounds like Sun. Connect the dots: Deliberately turning your back on someone/something.
extras.origin: Old English 'scunian' meaning to abhor or shrink back from fear. It implies an active, deliberate avoidance.

meanings.english: To be dead (usually murdered and body disposed of in water).

content.usage: If you cross the mafia, you might end up sleeping with the fishes.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Underwater bed. Visual: A gangster ties cement blocks to a victim's feet and throws him in the ocean. He sinks to the bottom and 'sleeps' there forever, surrounded by fish. Connect the dots: Being dead underwater.
extras.origin: Popularized by the movie *The Godfather* (1972), specifically the line about Luca Brasi. It is old Mafia terminology for disposing of a body in the sea.

meanings.english: To act foolishly; to take action that leads to inevitable trouble/war.

content.usage: By ignoring the grievances of the people, the government is sowing the dragon's teeth.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Dangerous seeds. Visual: In a myth, a hero plants teeth from a dragon into the soil like seeds. Instead of corn, armed skeleton soldiers grow out of the dirt and attack! Connect the dots: Doing something now that creates enemies later.
extras.origin: Greek Mythology. Cadmus (founder of Thebes) killed a dragon and sowed its teeth. Armed warriors (Spartoi) sprang up from the ground and fought him.

meanings.english: Postpone; to avert or delay something bad.

content.usage: He ate a snack to stave off hunger until dinner.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Stick defense. Visual: A pack of wolves attacks you. You have a heavy wooden staff (stave). You use it to push the wolves back, keeping them at a distance. Connect the dots: Fending off a threat temporarily.
extras.origin: 17th C. From 'stave' (part of a barrel). Originally 'stave in' meant to break a barrel. 'Stave off' meant using a staff/stick to keep dogs or enemies away.

meanings.english: To outshine; to gain an advantage secretly or unexpectedly.
meanings.hindi: चुपके से बाजी मार ले जाना; दूसरों से आगे निकल जाना।

content.usage: Our competitor stole a march on us by launching their product a week early.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Secret movement. Visual: Two armies are sleeping. One army wakes up at midnight and marches silently to the top of the hill. When the other army wakes up, they have lost the advantage. Connect the dots: Getting ahead by moving secretly.
extras.origin: Military tactic. Moving troops secretly (often at night) to gain a positional advantage before the enemy realizes what is happening.

meanings.english: Avoid; to keep a distance from.

content.usage: You should steer clear of bad company.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Driving away. Visual: You are driving a boat. You see sharp rocks ahead. You turn the steering wheel hard to go around them, keeping the boat safe. Connect the dots: Active avoidance of danger.
extras.origin: Nautical terminology. Captains had to 'steer clear' of rocks, shoals, or other ships to prevent collisions.

meanings.english: To be the most remarkable (often used ironically for something very bad or stupid).
meanings.hindi: हद कर देना (अक्सर नकारात्मक अर्थ में)।

content.usage: I've heard some dumb excuses, but that one takes the cake.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Winning prize. Visual: A dancing contest where the winner gets a delicious cake. If you win, you 'take the cake'. Used sarcastically: 'You are the winner of stupidity!' Connect the dots: Being the absolute best (or worst) example.
extras.origin: 19th C. African American 'cakewalk' competitions. Slaves would mock the formal dancing of owners; the best walker/dancer won a cake.

content.phrase: To take someone for a ride

meanings.english: To deceive someone; to cheat.

content.usage: I paid for a genuine leather jacket, but I think I was taken for a ride.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Kidnapping/Detour. Visual: A taxi driver picks up a tourist. Instead of going straight to the hotel, he drives in circles to charge more money. Connect the dots: Being misled or cheated.
extras.origin: American underworld slang (1920s). 'Taking someone for a ride' meant driving a victim to a secluded spot to murder them. Later softened to mean cheating/swindling.

meanings.english: To scold someone; to criticize/reprimand.

content.usage: The teacher took him to task for not completing his homework.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Assigned labor. Visual: A lazy worker is doing nothing. The boss grabs him and forces him to do a difficult 'task' as punishment. Connect the dots: Holding someone accountable or reprimanding them.
extras.origin: 16th C. To 'take someone to task' meant to assign them a specific job, or to demand an explanation for why a task wasn't done.

meanings.english: In every detail; exactly.

content.usage: He followed the instructions to the letter.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Character by character. Visual: You are copying a document. You don't just copy the words; you copy every single letter (A, B, C) exactly as it is written. Connect the dots: Following instructions precisely.
extras.origin: Short for 'to the last letter'. It implies observing a rule or instruction down to the smallest written character.

meanings.english: Express extreme anger; to have a tantrum.

content.usage: The toddler threw a fit when he couldn't get the candy.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Fake seizure. Visual: A child wants a toy. Mom says no. The child drops to the floor, screaming and shaking like they are having a medical 'fit' (seizure). Connect the dots: An explosive display of temper.
extras.origin: Medical metaphor. A 'fit' refers to a sudden attack of a disease (like epilepsy). A temper tantrum resembles the physical convulsions of a medical fit.

meanings.english: To follow the lead; to obey rules strictly.
meanings.hindi: नियमों का पालन करना; आदेश मानना।

content.usage: In the army, you have to toe the line or face punishment.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Foot alignment. Visual: Soldiers in assembly. The sergeant shouts, 'Line up!' Every soldier must put the tip of their boot (toe) exactly on the white line painted on the ground. Connect the dots: Strict obedience to rules.
extras.origin: Debated: 1) Soldiers lining up for inspection. 2) Sailors lining up on deck planks. 3) Runners at the starting line. All imply strict conformity.

content.phrase: To turn over a new leaf

meanings.english: To change one's behaviour for the better.
meanings.hindi: नया जीवन शुरू करना; सुधर जाना।

content.usage: After getting out of prison, he promised to turn over a new leaf.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Blank page. Visual: You have written many mistakes in your notebook. It looks messy. You grab the corner of the page (leaf) and turn it over. Now you have a fresh, blank white page to start again. Connect the dots: A fresh start.
extras.origin: 16th C. In printing and books, pages were called 'leaves'. Turning the leaf meant starting a new page/lesson, leaving the old errors behind.

meanings.english: In an ironic way; not seriously.

content.usage: His comment was meant tongue in cheek, so don't get offended.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Hidden laugh. Visual: Try to suppress a laugh. You press your tongue hard against the inside of your cheek. It makes a little bulge. Connect the dots: You are saying something serious, but your face shows you are holding back laughter.
extras.origin: 18th C. Originally a physical gesture to denote contempt or irony. Later evolved to mean insincerity or speaking jokingly.

meanings.english: Uncertain; precarious situation.
meanings.hindi: अनिश्चित; जो कभी भी बिगड़ सकता है।

content.usage: The surgery was touch and go, but he survived.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Brief contact. Visual: A ship sailing over shallow rocks. The bottom 'touches' the sand but the ship keeps 'going'. It almost crashed! Connect the dots: A delicate situation where success and failure are very close.
extras.origin: Nautical. A ship grazing the bottom of the sea but continuing to move. It implies a very narrow escape from disaster.

meanings.english: Turn upside down (usually a boat or car).

content.usage: The car skidded and turned turtle on the highway.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Flipped animal. Visual: A turtle on its back. Its legs wave in the air, and its shell is on the ground. It is helpless. Connect the dots: A car or boat that has flipped upside down looks exactly like that turtle.
extras.origin: Nautical terminology. Sailors used this to describe a boat capping (flipping over), resembling a turtle placed on its back.

meanings.english: Appear; arrive.

content.usage: He promised to come, but he didn't turn up.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Surface. Visual: You lost a key. You look everywhere. Suddenly, it 'turns up' under the sofa. Connect the dots: To show one's face or arrive.
extras.origin: Phrasal verb. Meaning to make an appearance or bring something to the surface.

meanings.english: To be angry; protesting vigorously.
meanings.hindi: विद्रोह पर उतारू; कड़ा विरोध करना।

content.usage: The residents were up in arms against the new construction project.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Holding weapons. Visual: A peaceful village gets angry. Everyone picks up rifles, pitchforks, and swords (arms) and holds them 'up' ready to fight. Connect the dots: Ready to fight or protest angrily.
extras.origin: Military. Literally meant rising up in rebellion with weapons (arms) in hand. Now metaphorically means furious protest.

meanings.english: Face to face; in relation to; compared with.

content.usage: We need to discuss our strategy vis-à-vis the competition.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Face to face. Visual: Imagine two French diplomats sitting directly across from each other at a table. 'Visage' means face. They are Vis-à-Vis. Connect the dots: Regarding or in comparison to.
extras.origin: French loanword meaning 'face to face'. Adopted into English in the 18th century.

meanings.english: To divert attention from something important (a small part controlling the whole).
meanings.hindi: ध्यान भटकाना; छोटी चीज का बड़ी चीज को नियंत्रित करना।

content.usage: The government started a war to wag the dog and distract from the scandal.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Tail control. Visual: A tiny tail shaking a giant dog. Usually, the dog controls the tail. If the tail moves the dog, something is wrong. Connect the dots: A small, unimportant part controlling the main entity to distract.
extras.origin: From the joke: 'Why does a dog wag its tail? Because the dog is smarter. If the tail were smarter, it would wag the dog.' Popularized by the movie *Wag the Dog*.

meanings.english: No longer important; past events that cannot be changed.
meanings.hindi: जो बीत गई सो बात गई; पुरानी बात।

content.usage: We had arguments in the past, but that is all water under the bridge now.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Gone flow. Visual: Stand on a bridge. Spit in the river. Watch the water carry it away. Can you get that specific water back? No, it's gone downstream to the ocean. Connect the dots: Past events that are gone forever.
extras.origin: River metaphor. The water that has flowed past is gone and cannot be recalled, just as past grievances should be let go.

meanings.english: Good and bad times; prosperity and misfortune.

content.usage: They promised to stay together through weal and woe.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Wealth & Sadness. Visual: A roller coaster named 'Life'. One peak is labelled 'Weal' (Wealth/Happiness), the drop is 'Woe' (Sadness). You ride both. Connect the dots: Through thick and thin; prosperity and pain.
extras.origin: Old English. 'Weal' meant wealth or well-being. 'Woe' meant misery. A rhyming couplet linking opposite fortunes.

meanings.english: Suffer unrequited love; to mourn a lost love.
meanings.hindi: वियोग में होना; प्यार में धोखा खाना।

content.usage: He has been wearing the green willow since she rejected his proposal.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Sad tree. Visual: A Weeping Willow tree. Its branches hang down like tears or hair covering a sad face. Someone wearing a wreath of willow branches is announcing their sadness in love. Connect the dots: Grieving for lost love.
extras.origin: Shakespearean/Folklore. The willow tree was a symbol of grief and unrequited love (e.g., Ophelia in *Hamlet* falls from a willow).

meanings.english: To prepare a ship to sail; to lift the anchor.

content.usage: We weigh anchor at dawn.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Lift weight. Visual: A ship is parked. To leave, sailors must pull the heavy anchor up from the seabed. They 'weigh' (lift) it until it hangs on the ship. Connect the dots: Starting a journey.
extras.origin: Nautical. 'Weigh' comes from archaic 'wegan' meaning to lift or carry. Weighing anchor simply means lifting it off the bottom.

meanings.english: To get drunk; to have a drink.

content.usage: He stopped at the pub to wet his whistle.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Dry flute. Visual: Think of your throat as a whistle or flute. If it's dry, it makes no sound. You pour liquid down it to 'wet' it so it works again. Connect the dots: Taking a drink to cure thirst.
extras.origin: Chaucer's *Canterbury Tales*. The 'whistle' referred to the throat/pipe. One needs to keep it wet (lubricated) to speak or sing.

meanings.english: What a coincidence (meeting someone unexpectedly).

content.usage: I met my old school friend in Paris—what a small world!

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Shrinking planet. Visual: You fly 5000 miles to a remote island. You walk into a cafe and see your neighbor from home. The giant world suddenly feels like a tiny village. Connect the dots: Unexpectedly meeting people far away.
extras.origin: Common 20th C. idiom used to express surprise at coincidental meetings.

meanings.english: Never going to happen; impossible.

content.usage: He will pay you back when pigs fly.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Heavy animals. Visual: Look at a pig. It is fat, heavy, and clumsy. Imagine pink wings on it. It flaps them, but *thud*, it stays on the ground. Connect the dots: Something that is physically impossible.
extras.origin: Adynaton (figure of speech for impossibility). The phrase 'pigs might fly' has been used since the 1600s to mock impossible ideas.

meanings.english: Pretend to be unafraid; to put on a brave front.

content.usage: He says he isn't worried about the exam, but I think he is just whistling in the dark.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Fear distraction. Visual: Walking down a spooky alley at night. You are terrified. To stop thinking about ghosts, you start whistling a happy tune loudly. Connect the dots: Making noise to hide your fear.
extras.origin: Refers to the actual practice of travelers whistling while walking at night to reassure themselves and scare off robbers/spirits.

meanings.english: Enjoy in a noisy way; to celebrate boisterously.

content.usage: The team went to whoop it up after winning the championship.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Cowboy party. Visual: Cowboys in a saloon celebrating. They fire guns in the air and yell 'YEE-HAW!' and 'WHOOP!' It is loud, wild, and fun. Connect the dots: Celebrating noisily.
extras.origin: 19th C. American slang. 'Whoop' is a loud cry of excitement or war. Cowboys 'whooping' meant a wild celebration.

meanings.english: Impossible to achieve; a deceptive goal or hope.

content.usage: Chasing perfection is a will-o-the-wisp.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Swamp ghost. Visual: You are in a swamp at night. You see a floating light (a wisp). You follow it, hoping it's a house. It moves away, leading you into deep mud. Connect the dots: A misleading hope that leads you astray.
extras.origin: Folklore. *Ignis fatuus* (foolish fire). A natural gas phenomenon creating lights over marshes, personified as a mischievous spirit (Will) leading travelers to doom.

meanings.english: To cheat/rob or defeat someone.

content.usage: The con artist wiped the nose of the tourist.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Treating like a baby. Visual: A mother wiping a baby's nose implies the baby is helpless. A con artist 'wipes the nose' of a victim by treating them like a helpless fool while stealing their wallet. Connect the dots: Cheating someone easily.
extras.origin: Old slang. Similar to 'wiping someone's eye' (shooting the game before they can). Implies rendering someone helpless or taking advantage of them.

meanings.english: Carefully; with great attention to detail.

content.usage: The police searched the house with a fine-tooth comb.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Lice hunt. Visual: You have a comb with teeth so tight together (fine) that nothing can pass through. You use it to catch tiny lice in hair. Nothing escapes. Connect the dots: Searching so carefully that no detail is missed.
extras.origin: Hygiene. Combs with closely spaced teeth were used to remove lice and nits from hair. Metaphorically applied to thorough investigations.

meanings.english: Excellent service; efficient and useful help in need.

content.usage: The volunteers did yeoman's service during the flood relief.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Loyal farmer. Visual: A Yeoman was a middle-class farmer/soldier in old England. They were known for being strong, loyal, and hardworking in battle and fields. Connect the dots: Hard, reliable, and valuable work.
extras.origin: Medieval England social class. Yeomen were freeholders below the gentry, famous for their skill with the longbow and reliable service to the crown.

meanings.english: Be very poor; living at subsistence level.

content.usage: Many families are living on the breadline due to unemployment.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Charity queue. Visual: It's the 1930s depression. Hungry people stand in a long line on the street waiting for a free loaf of bread from a charity. Connect the dots: Being so poor you rely on charity to eat.
extras.origin: Late 19th C. (USA). Refers to the physical line of people waiting for free food handouts from charities or bakeries during hard times.

meanings.english: To narrowly avoid a situation or disaster.

content.usage: I dodged a bullet by not investing in that company before it crashed.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Missed shot. Visual: You are in a gunfight (problem). A bullet is fired at your head. You lean back just in time (dodge), and it whizzes past your nose. Connect the dots: Narrowly escaping a catastrophic event.
extras.origin: Military/Combat metaphor. Literally avoiding being shot, extended to avoiding any negative outcome.

meanings.english: Smells foul; a bad smell.

content.usage: There was a terrible pen and ink coming from the garbage bin.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Rhyme time. Visual: Cockney Rhyming Slang uses rhymes to hide meaning. Say 'Pen and Ink'. What does it rhyme with? 'Stink!' Connect the dots: It's just a code word for a bad smell.
extras.origin: Cockney Rhyming Slang (London). The phrase 'Pen and Ink' rhymes with 'Stink'. Locals would say 'What a pen and ink!' to mean 'What a stink!'

meanings.english: To make someone laugh.

content.usage: His jokes always crack me up.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Face shattering. Visual: Imagine a stone statue with a serious face. Suddenly, cracks appear, and the face breaks open into a huge smile. Connect the dots: Breaking someone's composure with laughter.
extras.origin: Slang. To 'crack' implies losing control (cracking under pressure), but here it specifically means losing control of one's seriousness and bursting into laughter.

meanings.english: An easy and pleasant job; a highly desirable position.
meanings.hindi: मलाईदार नौकरी; आसान और अच्छी नौकरी।

content.usage: He landed a plum job at the embassy.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Juicy fruit. Visual: Pick a fruit from a basket. Do you want the dry crust or the juicy, sweet plum? The plum is the best treat. Connect the dots: A job that is sweet, rewarding, and easy to handle.
extras.origin: 17th C. slang. 'Plum' meant £100,000 or a very large sum of money. Later, it described anything desirable, especially a lucrative government post.

meanings.english: Made a mess; botched something up.

content.usage: He tried to fix the sink but made a pig's ear of it.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Floppy failure. Visual: You are trying to make a beautiful silk purse. But you fail, and it looks like a wrinkled, floppy, dirty pig's ear instead. Connect the dots: Turning something potential into a mess.
extras.origin: Mid-20th C. Contrasts with the proverb 'You can't make a silk purse out of a sow's (pig's) ear'. Making a pig's ear of something means ruining it.

meanings.english: Burst of energy after tiring.
meanings.hindi: नई ऊर्जा; पुनः शक्ति प्राप्त करना।

content.usage: I was tired at mile 10, but then I got my second wind and finished the marathon.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: New breath. Visual: A runner is gasping, out of breath (wind). Suddenly, their body adjusts, they breathe easily again, and they run faster. They found their 'second' breath. Connect the dots: Renewed energy.
extras.origin: Athletics. The physiological phenomenon where an athlete's breathing and heart rate stabilize after the initial period of exertion.

meanings.english: Provide useful advantage; everything can be used for profit.
meanings.hindi: फायदे का सौदा; काम की चीज।

content.usage: Every experience is grist to the mill for a writer.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Grind everything. Visual: A miller doesn't care what kind of grain (grist) you bring—wheat, barley, corn. He puts it all in the mill, and it all becomes useful flour. Connect the dots: Using every experience for profit.
extras.origin: 16th C. Milling terminology. 'Grist' is grain that has been separated from the chaff and is ready for grinding. For a miller, all grist is income.

meanings.english: Materialistic wealth or benefits.

content.usage: He is only interested in the loaves and fishes of the office, not the work itself.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Free lunch. Visual: Jesus performed a miracle feeding thousands with loaves and fishes. Some people followed him only for the free food, not the teachings. Connect the dots: Seeking material gain rather than spiritual/higher purpose.
extras.origin: Biblical (John 6:26). Jesus rebuked followers for seeking him not for the miracles, but because they 'did eat of the loaves and were filled'.

meanings.english: Exactly; perfectly.

content.usage: The suit fits him to a T.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Perfect fit. Visual: A carpenter uses a T-square tool. It draws perfect right angles and straight lines. If something fits 'to a T', it fits that perfect measurement. Connect the dots: Exact precision.
extras.origin: Uncertain. Theories: 1) From the T-square used by draftsmen. 2) Short for 'to a tittle' (a tiny mark/dot), implying attention to the smallest detail.

meanings.english: To tell others what to do; to be in control.

content.usage: Now that she is the manager, she calls the shots.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Marksman control. Visual: At a shooting range, the person with the gun shouts 'Pull!' to release the target. He decides when the action happens. Connect the dots: The person in charge of decision making.
extras.origin: Target shooting. A marksman would 'call' where their shot hit the target, or signal when to release the target.

meanings.english: A life filled with excitement and activity.

content.usage: Living in the fast lane can be exhausting after a while.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Speeding car. Visual: On the highway, the slow cars stay left. The Ferraris zoom in the 'fast lane' on the right. It's exciting, fast, and dangerous. Connect the dots: A lifestyle that is high-speed and risky.
extras.origin: Motoring terminology. The passing lane on a highway is the fast lane. Adopted metaphorically for a hedonistic or high-pressure lifestyle.

meanings.english: Smart and clever; cunning.

content.usage: He deceived everyone; he is as sly as a fox.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Trickster animal. Visual: A fox in a cartoon stealing a chicken while tricking the farmer. Foxes are famous for sneaking and outsmarting dogs. Connect the dots: Being cunning and deceptive.
extras.origin: Folklore/Fables (Aesop). The fox is universally depicted in western fables as the clever trickster who outwits stronger animals.

meanings.english: Completely different from each other.

content.usage: The two brothers are like chalk and cheese.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Looks similar, tastes different. Visual: Chalk is white and hard. Cheese is white/yellow and soft. Imagine eating chalk thinking it's cheese. Yuck! Totally different substance. Connect the dots: Superficially alike but fundamentally different.
extras.origin: 14th C. Proverb. Comparing two things that might look somewhat alike (white texture) but are completely different in nature and value.

content.phrase: As phony as a 3 dollar bill

meanings.english: Something that is fake; not genuine.

content.usage: His apology was as phony as a three-dollar bill.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Fake money. Visual: You get change at the store. The clerk hands you a bill with a '$3' printed on it. Wait! The government never printed a $3 bill. It's obviously fake. Connect the dots: Something clearly counterfeit.
extras.origin: American colloquialism. Since the US Treasury has never issued a $3 bill, the very concept represents something nonexistent and fake.

meanings.english: To look foolish; to be embarrassed because of a mistake.

content.usage: He had egg on his face after the project he championed failed miserably.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Messy face. Visual: You are giving a serious speech. Suddenly, you realize you have bright yellow egg yolk smeared all over your chin from breakfast. Everyone is laughing. Connect the dots: Looking ridiculous and embarrassed.
extras.origin: Early 20th C. Probably from the theater tradition where audiences threw rotten eggs at bad performers, leaving them humiliated and messy.

meanings.english: Desperate attempt to succeed; trying anything to find a solution.
meanings.hindi: मरता क्या न करता (तिनके का सहारा ढूंढना)।

content.usage: The police are just grasping at straws; they have no real evidence.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Drowning man. Visual: A man falls into a river. He is drowning. He sees a tiny piece of straw floating nearby. He grabs it frantically, hoping it will hold his weight. It won't. Connect the dots: Desperation.
extras.origin: From the proverb: 'A drowning man will catch at a straw'. It illustrates the futility of a desperate person relying on something too weak to help.

meanings.english: Average; ordinary; not special.

content.usage: It was just a run-of-the-mill movie, nothing exciting.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Factory standard. Visual: A fabric factory (mill). They produce thousands of yards of cloth every day. It's all the same, standard quality—nothing special, just the 'run' of the machine. Connect the dots: Ordinary/Average.
extras.origin: Textile manufacturing. Products that came directly from the mill without special selection or inspection were 'run of the mill'—standard quality.

meanings.english: To use one's last resource; to accept the poorest option because nothing else is left.
meanings.hindi: बचा-खुचा इस्तेमाल करना (क्योंकि और कुछ नहीं है)।

content.usage: They really scraped the barrel to find a candidate for the election.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Empty food bin. Visual: It's winter. The apple barrel is empty. You lean deep inside and scrape the rotten bits off the bottom because you are starving. Connect the dots: Using the worst/last options.
extras.origin: Food storage. Before refrigerators, food (like pork or apples) was stored in barrels. When supplies ran low, one had to scrape the bottom for the leftovers.

meanings.english: Bad luck.

content.usage: It was just bad iron that he got sick on the day of the interview.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Useless tool. Visual: You are a sheep shearer. You pick up your shears (iron), but they are blunt and rusty. You can't do your job. Bad luck! Connect the dots: Misfortune caused by poor circumstances.
extras.origin: Australian slang. Refers to shearing shears (irons). Getting a pair of 'bad irons' meant you couldn't shear quickly, costing you money.

meanings.english: Doing a job quickly; alert and efficient.

content.usage: The new assistant is really on the ball; she anticipates problems before they happen.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Sports focus. Visual: A soccer player. He isn't looking at the crowd. His eyes are locked 'on the ball'. If it moves, he moves instantly. Connect the dots: Being alert and ready to react.
extras.origin: Sports terminology (Cricket, Baseball, or Soccer). A player who keeps their eye 'on the ball' is attentive and effective.

meanings.english: Completely dead; obsolete; out of trend.
meanings.hindi: पूरी तरह से बेजान; जिसका अस्तित्व खत्म हो चुका हो।

content.usage: That old fashion trend is as dead as a doornail.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Permanent nail. Visual: In old doors, nails were hammered through and then bent over (clenched) on the other side so they could never be pulled out. They were 'dead' (immovable). Connect the dots: Totally lifeless/static.
extras.origin: 14th C. (Used by Shakespeare and Dickens). Refers to the practice of 'clenching' a nail, making it unusable for anything else—dead.

meanings.english: An unreal hope; an impossible plan.

content.usage: His plan to become a billionaire overnight is just a pipe dream.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Drug hallucination. Visual: A man in the 1800s smoking an opium pipe. He closes his eyes and sees himself flying on a dragon. Is it real? No, it's just a dream from the pipe. Connect the dots: A fantastic but impossible idea.
extras.origin: Late 19th C. Refers to the hallucinations and fantasies induced by smoking an opium pipe.

meanings.english: Obey someone's every wish; to follow someone around seeking to please them.

content.usage: I refuse to dance attendance on him just because he is rich.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Waiting servant. Visual: A bride dances at a wedding. Her servants stand on the sidelines, watching her every move, ready to jump if she needs water or a fan. They 'dance' to her needs. Connect the dots: Subservient waiting.
