extras.origin: 16th C. To 'dance attendance' meant to wait in the antechamber until a person of authority called for you, often implying kicking one's heels or moving about restlessly.

meanings.english: To buy something worthless (usually a car that breaks down constantly).

content.usage: I realized too late that the used car I bought was a lemon.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Sour deal. Visual: You buy a shiny orange car. You bite into it (drive it), and yuck! It's a sour lemon. It leaves a bad taste in your mouth. Connect the dots: A purchase that looks good but is defective.
extras.origin: Early 20th C. American slang. 'Lemon' meant a dud or something undesirable/sour. Later specifically applied to defective cars.

meanings.english: Starting to perform very well; functioning smoothly.
meanings.hindi: लय में होना; बेहतरीन प्रदर्शन करना।

content.usage: After a slow start, the team got in the groove and won the match.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Record player. Visual: Put a needle on a vinyl record. When it slips into the 'groove', the music plays smoothly and perfectly. Connect the dots: Finding the rhythm and performing well.
extras.origin: 1920s Jazz slang. When musicians played perfectly together or when the needle tracked the record groove perfectly, things were flowing.

meanings.english: Similar thing/person; an exact duplicate.

content.usage: He is a dead ringer for his father.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Fake horse. Visual: A dishonest racer swaps a slow horse for a fast look-alike (a ringer) to win a bet. 'Dead' means exact. Connect the dots: An exact duplicate.
extras.origin: Horse racing. A 'ringer' was a superior horse substituted for a slower one in a race. 'Dead' adds emphasis meaning 'exact'.

meanings.english: Made an irreversible change/decision.
meanings.hindi: निर्णायक कदम उठाना (जिससे वापसी संभव न हो)।

content.usage: By resigning from his job, he has crossed the Rubicon.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Caesar's river. Visual: Julius Caesar stands at a river (Rubicon). If he crosses with his army, it is war. He cannot go back. He steps into the water. Connect the dots: Taking a step from which there is no return.
extras.origin: 49 BC. Julius Caesar led his army across the Rubicon river into Italy, breaking Roman law and inevitably starting a civil war.

meanings.english: To become excited or angry; to go crazy.
meanings.hindi: पागल हो जाना (खुशी या गुस्से में)।

content.usage: The kids went bananas when I told them we were going to Disneyland.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Monkey excitement. Visual: Show a monkey a bucket of bananas. Does it sit quietly? No! It screams, jumps, and goes crazy. Connect the dots: Losing control with excitement or anger.
extras.origin: 1960s American slang. Likely linked to the stereotype of monkeys going into a frenzy when fed bananas.

meanings.english: An old vehicle (usually a car or ship) that is in bad condition.

content.usage: He drives an old rust bucket that makes a lot of noise.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Metallic trash. Visual: Imagine a metal bucket left in the rain for 20 years. It's orange with rust and full of holes. Now imagine driving that bucket. Connect the dots: A decrepit, rusty old vehicle.
extras.origin: Mid-20th C. Originally naval slang for an old, rusty destroyer or ship. Later applied to cars.

meanings.english: To go to bed.

content.usage: It's late; I'm going to hit the hay.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Straw mattress. Visual: In a barn, you fall onto a pile of soft hay to sleep. Before modern mattresses, people stuffed beds with hay. Connect the dots: Going to sleep.
extras.origin: Early 20th C. American slang. Mattresses were commonly stuffed with hay or straw.

meanings.english: An energetic person; a fine fellow.

content.usage: He's a real broth of a boy, always ready to help.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Strong soup. Visual: Broth is a thick, nutritious essence of meat. A 'broth of a boy' is the 'essence' of manhood—strong, spirited, and full of flavor. Connect the dots: A lively, sturdy fellow.
extras.origin: Irish Idiom. Broth signifies the essence or substance of something. So he is the essence of what a boy should be.

meanings.english: To gossip or chat casually.

content.usage: We sat around chewing the fat about old times.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Slow eating. Visual: Sailors eating salt pork. The fat is tough and rubbery. It takes forever to chew. What do they do while chewing? They talk and tell stories. Connect the dots: Long, leisurely conversation.
extras.origin: Nautical/Slang. Salt pork fat was hard to chew, giving sailors plenty of time to talk while eating. Alternatively, implies an idle activity.

meanings.english: Keep sharing the latest information; keep updated.

content.usage: Keep me posted on the status of the project.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Notice board. Visual: In the old days, news was written on paper and 'posted' (nailed) to a pole for everyone to see. Connect the dots: Ensuring someone gets the latest news.
extras.origin: Refers to the system of 'posting' letters or notices in public places or ledgers to keep records updated.

meanings.english: To annoy or upset someone.

content.usage: His arrogant comments really ruffled the feathers of the board members.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Angry bird. Visual: A bird sitting calmly is smooth. If it gets angry or scared, it puffs up (ruffles) its feathers to look bigger and fight. Connect the dots: Making someone agitated or annoyed.
extras.origin: Bird behavior. Birds ruffle their feathers when agitated, angry, or cold. Applied to humans to mean disturbing their composure.

meanings.english: I am not convinced; I don't believe it.
meanings.hindi: मैं नहीं मानता; मुझे विश्वास नहीं है।

content.usage: He says he was sick, but I don't buy it.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Refusing a sale. Visual: A salesman tries to sell you a broken watch (a lie). You shake your head and say, 'No, I won't buy that.' Connect the dots: Refusing to accept a statement as true.
extras.origin: Commercial metaphor. Accepting an idea or lie is equated to purchasing a product. If you don't 'buy' it, you don't take ownership of the belief.

meanings.english: A mild punishment.

content.usage: He got off with just a slap on the wrist for speeding.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Gentle hit. Visual: A child reaches for a cookie. Mom lightly taps (slaps) his wrist. It doesn't hurt; it's just a warning. Connect the dots: A punishment that is not severe.
extras.origin: 18th C. Educational/Legal. A minor physical reprimand compared to severe punishments like flogging or jail.

meanings.english: Market where prices are rising.

content.usage: Investors make more money during a bull market.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Attack style. Visual: How does a Bull attack? It lowers its head and thrusts its horns UP into the air. Connect the dots: A market where prices are going UP.
extras.origin: Stock Market. Bulls attack by thrusting horns *up* (rising prices), while Bears attack by swiping paws *down* (falling prices).

meanings.english: To be badly defeated; to meet one's final obstacle.

content.usage: After years of success, the politician met his Waterloo in the recent election.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Napoleon's end. Visual: Napoleon was the master of Europe. Unbeatable. Then he went to a place called Waterloo. He lost everything there. Connect the dots: A final, crushing defeat for someone successful.
extras.origin: Historical. Refers to the Battle of Waterloo (1815), where Napoleon Bonaparte was finally defeated by the Duke of Wellington, ending his rule.

meanings.english: To ease pressure on something; to be lazy.

content.usage: Don't slack off now; we are almost finished.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Loose rope. Visual: Tug of war. If you stop pulling hard, the rope becomes 'slack' (loose and droopy). Connect the dots: Working with less effort, making the tension drop.
extras.origin: Nautical. A 'slack' rope is one that is not taut or under tension. To 'slack off' meant to loosen a rope; metaphorically, to loosen effort.

meanings.english: Bought without proper examination; acceptance of something without checking.

content.usage: Buying a used car online is like buying a pig in a poke.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Bag trick. Visual: A 'poke' is a bag. A dishonest seller puts a stray cat in a bag and sells it as a delicious piglet. If you don't open the bag to check, you get tricked. Connect the dots: Buying blindly.
extras.origin: Medieval market trickery. Sellers would substitute a cat for a piglet in a tied bag (poke). If the buyer opened it, they 'let the cat out of the bag'.

meanings.english: To be idle; waiting with nothing to do.

content.usage: I was just twiddling my thumbs while waiting for the meeting to start.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Hand boredom. Visual: Clasp your hands together. Now spin your thumbs around each other. This is the only exercise you get when you are bored and waiting. Connect the dots: Doing nothing productive.
extras.origin: Descriptive gesture. This repetitive motion is commonly associated with boredom or impatience while having nothing to manipulate.

meanings.english: Neighbourhood; specific area.

content.usage: If you are ever in my neck of the woods, come visit me.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Strip of land. Visual: Imagine a forest. It has narrow strips (necks) of trees reaching out. 'My neck' is just my specific strip of land. Connect the dots: My specific local area.
extras.origin: Early American. 'Neck' referred to a narrow stretch of land (isthmus or peninsula) or a settlement in a wooded area.

meanings.english: To confine somebody in prison; to render powerless.

content.usage: The police finally laid the gang leader by the heels.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Stocks punishment. Visual: In medieval towns, criminals were put in 'stocks'—wooden boards with holes for ankles. Their heels were locked in, trapping them. Connect the dots: Imprisoning or trapping someone.
extras.origin: Medieval punishment. Referring to the use of stocks or bilboes (iron bars) to secure a prisoner by their ankles (heels).

meanings.english: To leave someone without support or direction.
meanings.hindi: बेसहारा छोड़ देना; मझधार में छोड़ना।

content.usage: After the company closed, the employees felt cast adrift.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Boat without oars. Visual: Putting a sailor in a small boat, taking away the oars, and pushing him into the open ocean. He drifts wherever the wind takes him. Connect the dots: Abandoning someone to fate.
extras.origin: Nautical. A boat that is 'adrift' floats without control. Casting a person adrift was a form of punishment or abandonment.

meanings.english: A mood of deep thoughts; reverie.
meanings.hindi: गहन चिंतन; ख्यालों में खोया हुआ।

content.usage: He sat in a brown study, ignoring the chaos around him.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Gloomy thoughts. Visual: See ID 1237. Imagine a dark, brown cloud of thought surrounding someone's head. Connect the dots: Deep, melancholy thinking.
extras.origin: From French 'brun' (gloomy). Originally meant gloomy thought, now just deep absorption.

meanings.english: Nonsense speech; complicated language that is hard to understand.
meanings.hindi: बकवास; समझ से बाहर की बात।

content.usage: The contract was full of legal mumbo jumbo.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Confusing chant. Visual: A masked tribal dancer chanting 'Mumbo Jumbo' to scare away spirits. To an outsider, the words mean nothing. Connect the dots: Language that sounds impressive but is meaningless.
extras.origin: From 'Mambo Jambo', a masked dancer/spirit in West African Mandingo tradition used to settle disputes. Early explorers found the rituals confusing.

meanings.english: To become angry suddenly.

content.usage: Be careful, he flies into a passion over small mistakes.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Take off. Visual: A bird sitting quietly. Suddenly—WHOOSH—it flies up into the air aggressively. Connect the dots: An emotion (passion/anger) that launches suddenly.
extras.origin: Metaphorical. 'Passion' used to mean any strong emotion (like anger). 'Flying into' implies sudden, rapid entry into that state.

meanings.english: Easily & quickly achievable; 'and there you have it'.

content.usage: Just press this button, and Bob's your uncle!

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Powerful relative. Visual: You want a government job. It's hard. But wait—Prime Minister Bob is your uncle! Suddenly, it's easy. You get the job instantly. Connect the dots: Everything is sorted out easily.
extras.origin: 1887 British politics. PM Robert (Bob) Cecil appointed his nephew Arthur Balfour to a high post. It implied success was guaranteed through nepotism.

meanings.english: Incomprehensible; hard to understand.
meanings.hindi: समझ से परे (काला अक्षर भैंस बराबर)।

content.usage: The technical manual was all Latin and Greek to me.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Dead languages. Visual: You open a book. It is written in ancient symbols (Greek) and old script (Latin). You can't read a word. Connect the dots: Something impossible for a normal person to understand.
extras.origin: Similar to 'It's all Greek to me' (from Shakespeare's *Julius Caesar*). These classical languages were the standard for 'difficult learning'.

meanings.english: Cowards.

content.usage: Don't be such a yellow belly; jump in the water!

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Lizard underside. Visual: A lizard or frog exposes its soft, yellow belly when it submits or is scared. Also, yellow is the color of fear. Connect the dots: A gutless coward.
extras.origin: Uncertain. Theories: 1) Yellow-bellied lizards/eels. 2) Derogatory term for people from the Lincolnshire Fens (frogs). 3) Traditional association of yellow with cowardice.

meanings.english: Gesture of peace.

content.usage: He extended an olive branch to his rival to end the feud.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Dove's gift. Visual: Noah's Ark during the flood. A dove returns carrying a green olive branch. This meant the flood was over and peace/land had returned. Connect the dots: An offer to end conflict.
extras.origin: Biblical (Genesis). The dove bringing an olive leaf to Noah signified that God's anger had ceased and the waters were receding.

meanings.english: Failing completely; wasted.
meanings.hindi: बर्बाद हो जाना; नाली में बह जाना।

content.usage: All our hard work went down the tubes when the project was cancelled.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Flushed away. Visual: You drop a ring in the sink. It goes down the drain pipe (tube). Can you get it back? No. It's gone into the sewer. Connect the dots: Something wasted and irretrievable.
extras.origin: Mid-20th C. Plumbing metaphor. Referring to waste being flushed down the drainpipes (tubes).

meanings.english: Go insane; to lose one's mind.

content.usage: Have you lost your marbles? You can't quit your job without a plan!

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Missing game pieces. Visual: Your brain is a bag of marbles. If the bag rips, the marbles roll away. Now the bag (head) is empty. You can't play the game of life anymore. Connect the dots: Losing your sanity.
extras.origin: Late 19th C. 'Marbles' was slang for 'wits' or 'common sense'. Losing them meant losing one's faculties.

meanings.english: Went terribly wrong.

content.usage: The plan went pear-shaped when it started raining.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Bad circle. Visual: A pilot tries to fly a perfect circle loop. He fails, and the bottom bulges out. It looks like a fat pear, not a circle. Connect the dots: A perfect plan that gets distorted and fails.
extras.origin: RAF (Royal Air Force) slang (1940s). Referred to a poorly executed aerial loop maneuver that looked like a pear instead of a circle.

meanings.english: A place having many interesting or valuable objects.

content.usage: The antique shop was a veritable Aladdin's cave.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Magical hoard. Visual: Aladdin says 'Open Sesame'. The rock opens to reveal a cave filled with gold, jewels, and magic lamps. Connect the dots: A place stuffed with treasures.
extras.origin: From *The Arabian Nights*. Aladdin discovers a magical cave filled with untold riches.

meanings.english: A painful cramp in the leg muscles.

content.usage: I got a bad charley horse while running the marathon.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Lame horse. Visual: You are running. Suddenly your leg stiffens up like an old, lame horse named Charley. It hurts to move. Connect the dots: A sudden, painful leg cramp.
extras.origin: 1880s Baseball slang. Possibly referring to a lame horse named Charley that pulled the roller on the Chicago White Sox ballpark.

meanings.english: Out of one's senses (usually with grief or anger).

content.usage: She was beside herself with grief when she heard the news.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Spirit separation. Visual: Imagine being so emotional that your soul steps out of your body and stands next to it. You are literally 'beside' yourself. Connect the dots: Being overwhelmed by emotion.
extras.origin: Ancient Greek/Biblical concept. Extreme emotion was thought to separate the soul/mind from the body.

content.phrase: At the drop of a dime

meanings.english: Happening fast without hesitation.

content.usage: He is ready to argue at the drop of a dime.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Instant connection. Visual: In old days, payphones cost a dime. You drop the dime in, and *click*—you are connected instantly. Connect the dots: Something happening immediately.
extras.origin: American. Variation of 'at the drop of a hat'. Also linked to the speed of making a call on a payphone.

meanings.english: In fashion; popular.

content.usage: Retro clothes are back in vogue this summer.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Fashion magazine. Visual: Think of *Vogue* magazine. If a dress is on the cover of *Vogue*, everyone wears it. Connect the dots: Being trendy and fashionable.
extras.origin: French word 'vogue' meant 'rowing' or 'course'. It evolved to mean 'on the current wave of popularity'. Popularized by the magazine.

meanings.english: A difficult situation; stirring up trouble.

content.usage: His controversial speech stirred up a hornet's nest.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Dangerous bugs. Visual: A paper nest hanging in a tree. It looks quiet. You poke it with a stick. SWARM! Hundreds of angry hornets attack you. Connect the dots: Provoking a chaotic and angry reaction.
extras.origin: Nature metaphor. Hornets are aggressive insects that attack in a swarm if their nest is disturbed.

meanings.english: Small steps; an affected or unnatural way of walking.
meanings.hindi: ठुमक कर चलना; नजाकत से चलना।

content.usage: She walked with a mincing gait that annoyed him.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Chopping steps. Visual: To 'mince' means to chop into tiny pieces. Imagine someone walking by chopping their stride into tiny, delicate, unnatural steps. Connect the dots: Walking with dainty affectation.
extras.origin: From 'mince' (to cut small). In the 16th C., it described acting with affected delicacy (mincing words or steps).

meanings.english: A person who thinks himself of high class; snobbish.

content.usage: The villagers found the new neighbors to be rather toffee-nosed.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Stuck up nose. Visual: Someone sticking their nose in the air. It's so stiff it looks like it's stuck with sticky toffee. They refuse to look down at common people. Connect the dots: Snobbish attitude.
extras.origin: British slang (early 20th C.). Possibly refers to the stiffness of a snob, or the idea of a nose stuck high in the air.

meanings.english: To feel extremely ashamed or embarrassed.

content.usage: I was so embarrassed I just wanted to curl up and die.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Disappearing act. Visual: A bug curls into a ball when threatened. You feel so much shame you want to curl into a ball and cease to exist so no one can see you. Connect the dots: Extreme embarrassment.
extras.origin: Hyperbolic expression of mortification. The desire to become small (curl up) and leave the situation permanently (die).

meanings.english: To perfection; dressed very fashionably.

content.usage: She was dressed to the nines for the gala dinner.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Max level. Visual: Imagine a scale of 1 to 10. For fashion, 9 is the highest single digit of perfection before hitting double digits. You are dressed to the absolute limit. Connect the dots: Perfection in dress or style.
extras.origin: Debated. Theories include: 1) The 99th Regiment of Foot ('The Nines') known for smart uniforms. 2) A reference to the 9 Muses. 3) A corruption of Old English 'to then eyne' (to the eyes).

meanings.english: Event that is likely to happen soon.

content.usage: There are big changes on the horizon for our company.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Distant view. Visual: Standing on a beach. You see a ship's mast appearing on the line where sky meets sea (horizon). It isn't here yet, but it is approaching. Connect the dots: An event that is coming soon.
extras.origin: Nautical/Visual metaphor. Objects on the horizon are visible but have not yet arrived; used metaphorically for future events.

meanings.english: Small part of a big organization; someone with a minor role.

content.usage: He felt like just a cog in the machine at the giant corporation.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Tiny gear. Visual: A giant factory machine the size of a house. Inside, there is one tiny metal tooth (cog) on a wheel. It spins all day. If it breaks, it's easily replaced. Connect the dots: An insignificant worker in a large system.
extras.origin: Industrial Revolution. As manufacturing moved from craftsmen to massive machinery, individual workers felt less like creators and more like interchangeable parts (cogs).

meanings.english: No longer young.

content.usage: At 60, he is no spring chicken, but he still runs marathons.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Old bird. Visual: A farmer selling chickens. The ones born in Spring are young, tender, and expensive. The old winter chickens are tough. If you are 'no spring chicken', you are the tough old bird. Connect the dots: Not young anymore.
extras.origin: 18th C. Agricultural. New England farmers sold chickens born in the spring for a higher price. An old bird trying to pass for young was called 'no spring chicken'.

meanings.english: Hard work; manual labour.

content.usage: He built this house by the sweat of his brow.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Forehead sweat. Visual: A construction worker hammering in the hot sun. He wipes his forehead (brow) because sweat is dripping into his eyes. He earned his money through physical pain. Connect the dots: Hard physical labor.
extras.origin: Biblical (Genesis 3:19). God tells Adam, 'In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread,' meaning he must work hard to survive after leaving Eden.

meanings.english: At the critical moment; at the time of decision.
meanings.hindi: मुश्किल घड़ी आने पर; निर्णायक समय पर।

content.usage: He promised to help, but when the crunch came, he disappeared.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Pressure point. Visual: You are holding a nut in a cracker. You squeeze. Nothing happens. You squeeze harder... *CRUNCH*. The shell breaks. That is the critical moment of pressure. Connect the dots: The decisive moment of crisis.
extras.origin: Modern usage. Likely related to 'Credit Crunch' or mechanical pressure. Winston Churchill used 'when the crunch comes' in 1939 regarding the test of war.

meanings.english: To perform without rehearsals; to decide what to do as the situation develops.
meanings.hindi: मौके के हिसाब से काम करना (बिना पूर्व योजना के)।

content.usage: We don't have a plan for the weekend yet; let's just play it by ear.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: No sheet music. Visual: A musician walks on stage. He lost his music notes! He has to listen to the band and just 'play by ear', guessing the notes as he goes. Connect the dots: Improvising without a plan.
extras.origin: Musical terminology. Playing an instrument 'by ear' means playing without reading sheet music, relying only on auditory memory and instinct.

meanings.english: Poor memory; forgets things easily.

content.usage: I need to write everything down because I have a memory like a sieve.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Leaky brain. Visual: Pour water into a bucket—it stays. Pour water into a sieve (strainer)—it all runs out the holes instantly. Your brain is the sieve; facts are the water. Connect the dots: Forgetting everything instantly.
extras.origin: Classical mythology/Kitchen metaphor. In the myth of the Danaids, they were punished by having to carry water in sieves, symbolizing loss and futility.

meanings.english: Strange person.

content.usage: He stays in his room all day and talks to himself; he's a bit of a queer fish.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Weird swimmer. Visual: A school of fish swims left. One fish swims upside down, backward, and wears a hat. That is a 'queer' (strange) fish. Connect the dots: An eccentric or strange person.
extras.origin: 18th C. Slang. 'Queer' originally meant strange, ill, or odd. Combined with 'fish' (referring to a person/bloke), it described someone with peculiar habits.

meanings.english: To make an attempt.

content.usage: I've never played golf before, but I'll have a bash.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Hit it. Visual: You are at a carnival game. You grab the hammer to 'bash' the target. You might miss, but you give it a strong hit anyway. Connect the dots: Making a vigorous attempt.
extras.origin: British informal slang. 'Bash' means a heavy blow. 'Having a bash' implies attacking a task with energy, even if unskilled.

meanings.english: Spoil someone's chance of doing something.

content.usage: He queered the pitch for me by telling the boss about my mistake.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Ruin the ground. Visual: A street performer finds a nice flat spot (pitch) to juggle. A rival comes and digs holes in the ground (queers/spoils it). Now he can't perform. Connect the dots: Sabotaging someone's plans.
extras.origin: 19th C. Market/Carnival slang. A 'pitch' was the spot a vendor/performer claimed. 'Queering' it meant spoiling the business there, perhaps by bribing police or causing trouble.

meanings.english: Great confusion; in a disordered manner.

content.usage: The children ran pell-mell out of the school when the bell rang.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Running blindly. Visual: A fire alarm rings. People don't walk in a line; they run 'pell-mell'—bumping into each other, tripping, mixing up directions. Connect the dots: Reckless, confused haste.
extras.origin: French 'pêle-mêle' (mixed up). Derived from 'mêler' (to mix). It describes a crowd moving in a disordered, confused mass.

meanings.english: Not brave; cowardly.

content.usage: He was too lily-livered to stand up to the bully.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: White organ. Visual: Old doctors believed the liver stored blood (courage). If you cut someone open and their liver was white like a lily flower, it had no blood. No blood = No courage. Connect the dots: Cowardly.
extras.origin: Medieval physiology (Humorism). A healthy liver was red with blood. A pale (lily) liver indicated a lack of blood, which was the fluid associated with bravery.

meanings.english: Make someone extremely angry or irritated.

content.usage: His constant complaining is driving me up the wall.

extras.mnemonic: Breakdown: Escaping frustration. Visual: You are locked in a room with an annoying person. They are so irritating you want to escape by literally climbing up the vertical walls like a spider. Connect the dots: Frustration so high you defy gravity.
extras.origin: 20th C. Hyperbolic expression. Describing someone so desperate to escape an annoyance or frustration that they would try to climb the walls.
